POISON

Poisons come in many forms, and might be applied to a weapon, ingested with a meal, or breathed in while exploring a deadly dungeon.

Poisons are categorized with three types of tags:

  • Rarity denotes how common a poison is. Poison will be Common, Uncommon, Rare, Very Rare, or Mythical.
  • Lethality denotes how dangerous a poison is. Lower-lethality poisons are typically much more common.
  • Transmissibility denotes how likely the effects of the poison are to spread to another target. High transmissibility is very uncommon for poisons.

Several abilities might allow you to ignore or treat poisons of a certain level of rarity. Lethality and transmissibility are not referenced in the Core Rulebook, but will come into play in later releases as the peoples of Ancerra become more medically advanced.

Poison stat blocks have three parts: Application, Symptoms, and Treatment.

Application explains what must happen for a creature to suffer from the poison: is it ingested, breathed, or do you simply touch it?

Symptoms breaks down the poison’s symptoms in increments of time. Slow-acting poisons might have day-by-day symptomatic progressions, while fast acting ones might be minute-by-minute or even round-by-round.

Treatment explains what one must do to become cured of the poison. This typically involves some kind of antidote, magical healing, and/or successful INT/Medicine checks.

BASILISK-EYE GOO

Very Rare Poison

Lethality: High

Transmissibility: None

Application: A creature gains Basilisk-Eye poisoning when being successfully struck with a weapon coated in Basilisk-Eye goo, a very rare and difficult to create poison distilled from a fresh Basilisk eye.

Symptoms: An infected creature gains the following symptoms at the start of each of the following days (after Taking a Rest, if they were able to Rest). The effects are cumulative.

  • Day 1: Gain Shaken as slight tremors rack your hands and feet.
  • Day 2: Gain Slowed as your joints lock up.
  • Day 3+: Make a DC 18 END check. On a failure, you become Petrified as your skin turns to rough stone. If successful, you do not gain any additional symptoms. Repeat this check every day.

Treatment: Curing Basilisk-Eye poisoning requires a successful DC 15 INT/Medicine check that includes a salve made from crushed diamond. This check consumes the salve, which costs at least 200 sc. Additionally, an infected individual is cured if they successfully make three END checks to avoid Petrification. A creature that is Petrified can be cured with Greater Restoration and similar magic.

DEEPSHROOM TOXIN

Very Rare Poison

Lethality: Medium

Transmissibility: High

Application: A creature gains Deepshroom Poisoning when consuming food or drink laced with Deepshroom Toxin or by breathing in Deepshroom spores.

Symptoms: An infected creature gains the following symptoms at the start of each of the following hours. The effects are cumulative.

  • Hour 1-4: Become Shaken from convulsive coughing and shallow breathing. Roll 1d20 each hour; on an 1-3, you instead gain the Suffocating condition. A DC 15 INT/Medicine check replaces this condition with Shaken.
  • Hour 5-9: Dark purple mushrooms begin to sprout from your skin, especially around your eyes and mouth. Your eyes turn a jaundiced yellow. You gain Iron Will and Steel Mind as a fog takes hold in your brain. You also cannot benefit from the Focused or Rallied conditions.
  • Hour 10-12: The mushrooms begin to release Deepshroom Spores. All creatures within 15 ft must make a DC 17 END check, becoming infected with Deepshroom Poisoning if they fail. Gain the Blinded and Silenced condition as the mushrooms continue to sprout.
  • Hour 13-17: Make a DC 17 END check. On a success, gain Fatigue and make this roll again the following hour. If you fail, you immediately transform into a Deepshroom Shambler and gain the appropriate stat block, losing all of your previous features. You can no longer tell friend from foe and must seek out living humanoids to infect with Deepshroom Poisoning.
  • Hour 18: If you make enough successful END checks to reach hour 18 without transforming, you do not transform into a Deepshroom Shambler and instead immediately die.
  • Day 7: A Deepshroom Shambler transforms into a Deepshroom Hive after 7 days.

Treatment: Curing the Deepshroom Toxin requires one or more DC 18 INT/Medicine checks that require herbs and bandages. If the check is made with anti-fungal cream or while in direct sunlight, the DC is lowered to 13. Each check consumes one use of herbs, bandages, and cream. You cannot receive more than 1 check per hour. If turned into a Deepshroom Shambler, Greater Restoration and similar magic can restore you to merely being infected as though in Hour 4 of having consumed Deepshroom Toxin.

Laxberry Syrup

Common Poison

Lethality: None

Transmissibility: None

Application: A creature must consume Laxberry Syrup to become infected with this poison.

Symptoms: 1d4 hours after consumption, there is an explosive flushing of the digestive system. Gain Stunned for 1d4 rounds, and then face no further effects.

Treatment: There is no way to treat Laxberry Syrup short of magical intervention. If a creature wishes to ignore the effects of Laxberry Syrup, they must make a DC 12 END check when the symptoms would manifest. If successful, they may delay the symptoms by 30 seconds. Each subsequent time that the symptoms would occur, the creature may repeat the END check, but the DC increases by +2 for each attempt.

NIGHTSHADE EXTRACT

Rare Poison

Lethality: High

Transmissibility: Low

Application: A creature gains Nightshade Poisoning through direct ingestion or by a successful attack with a weapon coated in nightshade extract.

Symptoms: An infected creature gains the following symptoms at the start of each of the following hours. The effects are cumulative.

  • Hour 1: Become Sickened as veins around the wound site become pronounced and black. You lose ¼ of your max HP while infected with this poison.
  • Each additional hour after 1: Make a DC 15 END check. On a fail, gain Fatigue and lose an additional ¼ of your max HP.
  • If you are reduced to 0 HP by this poison you immediately die.

Treatment: Curing Nightshade Extract requires one or more DC 17 INT/Medicine checks that require herbs and bandages. Each check consumes one use of herbs and bandages. You cannot receive more than 1 check per hour.

Additionally, you are cured of Nightshade Poisoning if you make three successful END checks.

Poison Oak Sap

Uncommon Poison

Lethality: None

Transmissibility: Low

Application: A creature is afflicted with Poison Oak Poisoning when it comes in direct contact with their skin or when a weapon coated in Poison Oak Sap hits them.

Symptoms: An infected creature gains the following symptoms at the start of each day after Taking a Rest. These symptoms are cumulative.

  • Day 1: Gain a mildly itchy rash and Demoralized.
  • Day 2: The rash spreads and becomes significantly more itchy. Gain Chilled.
  • Day 3: The rash spreads and becomes unbearably itchy. Gain Sickened.
  • Day 4: The rash reaches its most unbearable stage. Gain Slowed and Helpless.
  • Day 5: The rash begins to dry up. Remove Slowed or Helpless.
  • Day 6: The rash continues to dry up. Remove Sickened.
  • Day 7: Remove Chilled.
  • Day 8: Full recovery.

Treatment: The afflicted area of skin must be completely scrubbed down with lemon juice and then caked in lye soap, the suds left to dry into a crust. Correctly applying the antidote requires a DC 10 INT/Medicine check. Successfully applying the antidote advances the creature’s symptoms by 1 day. A creature can only benefit from this treatment once every 8 hours.

SWAMP-POD SLIME

Rare Poison

Lethality: Low

Transmissibility: None

Application: A creature gains Swamp-Pod Poisoning when directly consuming Swamp Pods or drinking something laced with Swamp-Pod Slime.

Symptoms: An infected creature gains the following symptoms at the start of each of the following days (after Taking a Rest, if they were able to Rest). The effects are cumulative.

  • Day 1: Become Dazed as you dissociate from reality while small red spots appear in your armpits. Every 4 hours, make a DC 15 CHA check. On a failure, you experience a minor hallucination for 1 minute. This hallucination includes all senses related to what you experience and seems completely real to you.
  • Day 2: The spots spread to cover the base of your neck. Every 4 hours, make a DC 20 CHA check. On a failure, you gain the Phobic condition as you experience a major hallucination for 10 minutes. This hallucination includes all senses related to what you experience, seems completely real to you, and includes something that terrifies you as the source of your phobia. You also become paranoid and no longer trust those around you. Every additional failed CHA check makes the hallucinations worse.

Treatment: Curing Swamp-Pod poisoning requires one DC 16 INT/Medicine checks that require herbs. Each check consumes one use of herbs. You cannot receive more than 1 check per hour. Additionally, you are cured of Swamp-Pod Poisoning after 48 hours.

Vampire Wine

Mythic Poison

Lethality: High

Transmissibility: Low

Application: A creature must consume Vampire Wine to become infected with this poison.

Symptoms: An infected creature gains the following symptoms at the start of each corresponding minute after initially consuming the poison. The effects are cumulative.

  • Minute 10: Feel excruciating pain. Gain Staggered.
  • Minute 11: Gain +1 Death Point.
  • Minute 12: Gain Helpless.
  • Minute 13: Gain +1 Death Point.
  • Minute 14: Gain Bleeding (1). This can only be cured by successfully treating the poison.
  • Each Subsequent Minute: Gain +1 Death Point.

Upon death, the creature’s blood remains potent for an hour, during which time any ingestion or exposure to an open wound will cause the poison to attack the new victim.

Treatment: A thick paste of fresh garlic and blood thinner must be injected directly into the creature’s veins. This requires a DC 26 INT/Medicine check. If this treatment fails, then the creature is beyond saving. If the treatment succeeds, then the poison becomes impotent once the creature has 7 Death Points.

DISEASE

“Disease” is a term used loosely in this context to refer to any sort of pathogenic alien entity that enters one’s body. This could technically be a disease, infection, or virus, but all three are simply referred to as diseases for the purposes of game mechanics.

Diseases are categorized in the same way as poisons, with Rarity, Lethality, and Transmissibility. As with poisons, Lethality and Transmissibility are not referenced in the Core Rulebook, but will come into play in later releases.

Disease stat blocks have five parts: Infection, Outbreak, Contagion, Symptoms, and Treatment.

Infection explains what must happen for a creature to become infected.

Outbreak is an optional tool that an MC can use when facilitating the outbreak of a disease.

Contagion explains how quickly the disease might spread, and how to determine whether it spreads to certain heroes or relevant NPCs.

Symptoms convey on an hour-by-hour or day-by-day basis what happens to an infected creature.

Treatment informs you on the steps you must take to cure a disease. This will typically involve making multiple INT/Medicine checks, and certain expensive ingredients or magical healing abilities might make this process easier or might be required to even attempt this process.

BEASIAN BOILS

Very Rare Disease

Lethality: Medium

Transmissibility: High

Infection: A creature gains Beasian Boils when they are hit with a Blood Beast’s Rip and Tear ability.

Outbreak and Contagion: Beasian Boils spread when Blood Beasts or their spawn hit with specific attacks, so creatures only contract this disease through combat.

Symptoms: An infected creature gains the following symptoms at the start of each of the following days (after Taking a Rest, if they were able to Rest). The effects are cumulative.

  • Day 1: Become Sickened as brown-green boils blister up just beneath your skin. Some might burst and ooze fluorescent lime green gunk.
  • Day 2: You gain Iron Will and Steel Mind as a fog takes hold in your brain. You also cannot benefit from the Focused or Rallied conditions.
  • Day 3: While in combat, when you are Bloodied, you have Bleeding (1d4) as more of your pustules split open. Coarse hair begins sprouting along your body.
  • Day 4: Make an END check. If you roll above a 17, you gain Fatigue and make this roll again on the following day.

If you roll below a 17 on or after Day 4, you transform into a Blood Beast Spawn. As a Blood Beast Spawn, you have the stats of a Dire Hyena and can no longer distinguish ally from enemy. When you hit someone with your Bite attack, make a secondary attack: +3 vs FORT. Hit: The creature contracts Beasian Boils.

Treatment: Curing the Beasian Boils requires one or more INT/Medicine checks. Each check must include herbs and bandages soaked in medicinal salves mixed with silver shavings. Each application of this medicine costs at least 80 sc, which the process consumes. You cannot receive more than 1 check per 24 hours.

The DC to treat this disease is 17. If you receive treatment within 24 hours of being hit, you are cured. Otherwise, you need to receive two successful treatments to be cured.

If you are a Blood Beast Spawn, Greater Restoration and similar magic can remove the disease and restore you to your previous state.

BOIL PLAGUE

Common Disease

Lethality: Low

Transmissibility: Extreme

Infection: Boil Plague spreads through physical contact. Creatures that suffer Boil Plague break out in running sores whose oils carry infection.

Outbreak: 5d20 creatures in an urban area contract Boil Plague.

Contagion: At the end of each day, Xd20 additional creatures are infected, where X equals the number of days since the outbreak. Subtract 1 die from this roll (to a minimum of 0d20) for every 20 infected creatures that have remained at least partially quarantined for the past 24 hours and have received adequate hygienic care (washing the sores, keeping hands clean, etc.). If all infected creatures are partially quarantined and receive adequate hygienic care, the disease does not spread.

If you need to determine whether a specific PC or NPC contracts the disease, make an attack against that creature’s FORT. The attack bonus is +1 per 1 minute the creature has spent in close proximity to one or more infected creatures, to a maximum of +20.

Symptoms: A creature gains progressively worse symptoms the longer that they are infected. Once a creature is infected, they become infectious and can spread the disease 1d3 hours later. Once the creature is infectious, then it gains the following symptoms at the start of each of the following days. These effects are cumulative.

  • Day 1: Shaken
  • Day 2: Sickened
  • Day 3: Staggered
  • Day 4: Remove the Staggered condition
  • Day 5: Remove the Sickened condition
  • Day 6: Remove the Shaken condition
  • Day 7: Creature fully recovers

Creatures that suffer Boil Plague and recover have nasty pockmarks that rarely fade completely, but fade to being barely noticeable after 2d12 months. Creatures that suffer Boil Plague and recover become immune to Boil Plague for 1 year.

Treatment: Treating a creature with the Boil Plague requires a DC 15 INT/Medicine check. If you succeed, then the creature’s symptoms rapidly progress. Over the next hour, that creature’s symptoms advance by 1d3 days. A creature can benefit from this treatment only once while infected with Boil Plague.

DEATHBOIL PLAGUE

Rare Disease

Lethality: High

Transmissibility: Medium

Infection: Deathboil Plague spreads through physical contact. An infected creature’s boils and pustules will frequently burst, making treatment a messy process. These burst oils spread rapidly and infect other creatures that come into contact with them.

Outbreak: 5d10 creatures in an urban area contract Deathboil Plague.

Contagion: At the end of each day, Xd10 additional creatures are infected, where X equals the number of days since the outbreak. Subtract 1 die from this roll (to a minimum of 0d10) for every 10 infected creatures that have remained completely quarantined for the past 24 hours. If all infected creatures are quarantined, the disease does not spread.

If you need to determine whether a specific PC or NPC contracts the disease, make an attack against that creature’s FORT. The attack bonus is +1 per 5 minutes the creature has spent in close proximity to one or more infected creatures, to a maximum of +20.

Symptoms: A creature gains progressively worse symptoms the longer that they are infected. Roll 1d3. A creature that is exposed to the disease takes that many days to incubate. Once they have incubated, the disease is potent and can spread to other creatures. Additionally, once the creature has incubated, then it gains the following symptoms at the start of each of the following days. These effects are cumulative.

  • Day 1: Shaken.
  • Day 2: Sickened.
  • Day 3: Slowed.
  • Days 4-14: Gain Fatigue. During this period, infected creatures have blotches of blackened or otherwise discolored skin.
  • Days 11-14: If a creature is not cured by day 10 or later, it must lose a randomly determined limb in order for the treatment to be successful.

Creatures that suffer Deathboil Plague and recover often have terrible scars for the rest of their lives, including divots in their skin where their necrosis was carved off of their body.

Treatment: Treating a creature with the Deathboil Plague requires a DC 20 INT/Medicine check. If you succeed, then the creature’s symptoms do not progress for the day. If you treat the same creature two days in a row and are successful both times, then the creature is cured and is immune to Deathboil Plague for 1 year.

DEEPSHROOM POISONING

Rare Disease

Lethality: High

Transmissibility: Low

Infection: When a creature inhales a Deepshroom Hive’s cloud of spores, it becomes infected with Deepshroom Poisoning.

Symptoms: An infected creature gains the following symptoms at the start of each of the following days (after Taking a Rest, if they were able to Rest). The effects are cumulative.

  • Day 1: Demoralized.
  • Day 2: Shaken.
  • Day 3: Sickened.
  • Days 4-6: Gain Fatigue.
  • Day 7: The creature dies.
  • Day 7+1d4: The creature rises as a Deepshroom Shambler.

Treatment: Curing Deepshroom Poisoning requires one or more INT/Medicine checks. Each check must include herbs and medicinal salves worth at least 30 sc each, which the process consumes. A creature cannot receive more than 1 check per 12 hours. When a creature makes this check, note the numerical result and add it to any previous checks from this instance of Deepshroom Poisoning. When the numerical results reach a cumulative total of 30, the infection is cured.

FLESHLING FEVER

Rare Disease

Lethality: High

Transmissibility: Low

Infection: M’l’ykkri Flesh Swarms and M’l’ykkri Flesh Worms can both cause a creature to gain Fleshling Fever.

Symptoms: An infected creature gains the following symptoms at the start of each of the following hours. The effects are cumulative.

  • Hour 1: Demoralized.
  • Hour 2: Slowed.
  • Hours 3-12: Gain Fatigue.
  • Upon Death: Become a M’l’ykkri Fleshling and 2d4 M’l’ykkri Flesh Worms emerge from the corpse.

Treatment: Curing Fleshling Fever requires one or more INT/Medicine checks. Each check must include herbs and medicinal salves worth at least 20 sc each, which the process consumes. A creature cannot receive more than 1 check per 30 minutes. When a creature makes this check, note the numerical result and add it to any previous checks from this instance of Fleshling Fever. When the numerical results reach a cumulative total of 75, the infection is cured.

When the infection is cured, 2d4 M’l’ykkri Flesh Worms emerge from the healed body.

GIFT OF THE CHOSEN

Rare Disease

Lethality: High

Transmissibility: Medium

Infection: A creature might contract Gift of the Chosen if exposed to another infected individual.

Outbreak: If an outbreak occurs, a ghost ship appears. When 20 or more creatures have a form of Chosen Madness in a single settlement of 200 or more individuals, roll percentile dice at dusk each night. On a roll of 76-100, a ghost appears in port between dusk and dawn each morning. It is crewed by 5d4 Chosen Crewmates, 1d4 Chosen Boatswains, and 1 Chosen Captain. While a ghost ship is in the port or the settlement, a dense fog covers the whole settlement. This fog persists so long as the ghost ship is in port and cannot be removed by magical means. So long as this fog persists, creatures looking for the settlement must succeed on a DC 16 INT/Navigating check in order to find it.

Contagion: Any humanoid within 10 ft of an infected individual while they have the Insane Babbling symptom or while proselytizing must make a DC 15 CHA check or gain one Madness symptom from the following table. Anyone who reads a scroll or tome infected with Gift of the Chosen must make a DC 18 CHA check or immediately become infected and make 3 Chosen Madness table rolls.

These tomes and scrolls are common within some cults.

Symptoms: 24 hours after infection, a creature must roll 1d6 and gain a permanent effect from the following Chosen Madness table. This roll must be repeated for every additional 24 hours of infection. If a creature rolls an effect that it already has, it gains no additional madness for that day.

If a creature gains all six symptoms from the Chosen Madness table, it is immediately transformed into a Chosen Crewmate.

1 - Uncontrollable Weeping/Laughing.

2 - Terrifying Hallucinations.

3 - Extreme Paranoia.

4 - Masochistic.

5 - Insane Babbling.

6 - Blissful Delirium.

Treatment: Curing Gift of the Chosen requires one or more DC 18 INT/Religion or INT/Medicine checks. An infected individual needs X successful checks, where X equals the number of Chosen Madness symptoms that they suffer from. This treatment can be attempted once every 12 hours. Greater Restoration and similar magic immediately cures the Gift of the Chosen without additional checks, and Lesser Restoration and similar magic counts as two successful checks.

SCARLET SICKNESS

Rare Disease

Lethality: High

Transmissibility: High

Infection: A creature might contract Scarlet Sickness if an open wound is exposed to blood from another creature. Once a creature is infected, their blood becomes infectious regardless of if other creatures have open wounds or not.

Outbreak: 1d4 creatures gain Scarlet Sickness.

Contagion: At the end of each day, all creatures exposed to Scarlet Sickness must make a DC 15 END check. On a fail, a creature gains Scarlet Sickness.

Symptoms: A creature exposed to Scarlet Sickness becomes symptomatic and infectious 1d4 hours after contracting the sickness. Once a creature is infectious, incubated, then it gains the following symptoms at the start of each of the following hours. These effects are cumulative unless noted otherwise.

  • Hour 1: Sickened.
  • Hour 2: Fatigued.
  • Hour 3: Bleeding (1d4)
  • Hour 4: Bleeding (1d6) - this replaces the hour 3 symptom.
  • Hour 5: Bleeding (1d8) - this replaces the hour 4 symptom.
  • Hour 6: Bleeding (1d10) - this replaces the hour 5 symptom.
  • Hour 7: Bleeding (1d12) - this replaces the hour 6 symptom.

Creatures that suffer Scarlet Sickness and recover often have terrible laceration scars for the rest of their lives.

Treatment: Treating a creature with the Scarlet Sickness requires a DC 25 INT/Medicine check. If you succeed, then the creature’s symptoms do not progress for the hour. If you successfully treat the same creature two hours in a row, then the creature is cured and is immune to Scarlet Sickness for 6 months.

STONEROT

Uncommon Disease

Lethality: Low

Transmissibility: High

Infection: A creature gains Stonerot when they are hit with a Sickening Statue’s Infectious ability.

Outbreak and Contagion: Stonerot only spreads through direct contact, so creatures only contract this disease through combat or through failing an attribute check.

Symptoms: An infected creature first undergoes an asymptomatic incubation period. Roll 1d6+1; after that many days, the symptoms begin appearing. An infected creature gains the following symptoms at the start of each of the following days (after Taking a Rest, if they were able to Rest). The effects are cumulative.

  • Days 1-3. You are Slowed. Your skin around the area of exposure looks hard, cracked, and gritty, like rough rock.
  • Day 4-6. You are Frozen. The skin infection spreads and your joints stiffen.
  • Days 7-10. You are Staggered as the infection overtakes most of your body.
  • Days 11-13. You are Petrified.
  • Day 14. You lose any conscious retention of who you are and become a Sickening Statue. You can no longer distinguish friend or foe, you no longer need to eat, drink, or sleep, and you lurk and wait for easy prey to whom you can spread the disease.

Treatment: Curing Stonerot requires one or more INT/Medicine checks. Each check must include medicinal salves or holy water worth at least 10 sc each, which the process consumes. You cannot receive more than 1 check per 24 hours.

When a creature makes this check, note the numerical result and add it to any previous checks from this instance of Stonerot. When the numerical results reach a cumulative total of 100, the infection is cured. If cured, you regain memories of your life prior to becoming a Sickening Statue after 1d4 days.

Vampirism

Uncommon Disease

Lethality: Extreme

Transmissibility: High

Infection: A creature gains Vampirism when they are bitten three times in the span of 24 hours by one or more vampires.

Symptoms: An infected creature gains the following symptoms at the start of each of the following days. The effects are cumulative.

  • Day 1: Become Demoralized.
  • Day 2: You become irritable and lash out at minor provocations (no mechanical effect).
  • Days 3 on until Cured: Gain Fatigue.
  • Upon Death: Become a vampire (see the following “Becoming a Vampire” section).

Treatment: Curing Vampirism requires a combination of divine healing and herbal concoctions. A creature may only be cured of Vampirism before dying; once they die and become a vampire, this is an irreversible condition.

For a creature to be cured of Vampirism, they must be the recipient of the Lesser Restoration or Greater Restoration divine ritual. If they received Lesser Restoration, then they must also receive two doses of a special potion; if they received Greater Restoration, then they only need to receive one dose. A creature may not benefit from both Lesser Restoration and Greater Restoration for the purposes of overcoming this infection.

The potion consists of a blend of garlic and holy water. After grinding down and blending the ingredients, a creature must boil them together and then feed them to the infected creature while the liquid is still simmering. This deals 1d4 fire damage to the creature.

To successfully make the potion, the creature blending together the ingredients may make a DC 14 INT check using the Alchemy or Medicine skills. A player that makes a compelling case for another skill (such as Arcana, Cooking, or Religion) may use it at the MC’s discretion, though using a different skill raises the DC to 16.

A creature may only receive one portion of the treatment (Lesser Restoration or Greater Restoration, and the potion doses) at a time and must Take a Rest between each treatment.

Becoming a Vampire: Once a hero becomes a vampire, the hero becomes an NPC. An NPC that becomes a vampire gains the stats of a Vampire Spawn or Vampire at the MC’s discretion.

ZOMBIE PLAGUE

Uncommon Disease

Lethality: Extreme

Transmissibility: High

Infection: A creature gains Zombie Plague when they are hit with a Zombie’s bite attack and the secondary infection attack that comes with it.

Outbreak and Contagion: Zombie Plague does not spread through living creatures, so has no Outbreak or Contagion rules.

Symptoms: An infected creature gains the following symptoms at the start of each of the following days (after Taking a Rest, if they were able to Rest).

The effects are cumulative.

  • Until Treated: Gain Fatigue twice.
  • Upon Death: Become a Zombie in 1d4 hours.

Treatment: Curing the Zombie Plague requires one or more INT/Medicine checks. Each check must include herbs and medicinal salves worth at least 20 sc each, which the process consumes. You cannot receive more than 1 check per 24 hours.

When a creature makes this check, note the numerical result and add it to any previous checks from this instance of zombie plague. When the numerical results reach a cumulative total of 40, the infection is cured.

INSANITY

Beyond the shelter of civilization, untold horror awaits in the dark recesses of the wilderness. Sometimes, the blackened alleys of an oppressed city and hidden basements of mad scientists hold horrors just as foul. Adventuring often brings heroes face to face with terrifying monsters and maddening experiences.

When your heroes come face to face with abject terror, you might make them roll for insanity. Insanity should primarily change a character’s outlook on the world and be a roleplay tool, although the worst effects of insanity will also have mechanical detriments attached. Be mindful of your players’ yellow and red zones when implementing any of these effects.

Depending on the type of horror that confronts the heroes, you might ask each hero to make an AWR, INT, or CHA check. The higher their roll, the more minor the insanity effect, and a very high roll might allow a hero to shrug off any insanity altogether. The lower the roll, the worse or longer-lasting a hero’s insanity will be.

One of the most rewarding treasures that heroes might find at the end of a quest is magic items. Flaming swords, armor that absorbs energy and converts it into power, rope that climbs walls by itself… any number of magic items might appeal to your adventurers for a variety of reasons. This chapter offers some guidance on creating your own magic items, then offers a codex of premade magic items ready to use in any game.

EQUIPPING MAGIC ITEMS

Magic items require some of the bearer’s Essence, or their life energy, in order to function. By default, an adventurer has 100 Essence Points. An adventurer cannot equip items whose sum Essence cost exceeds this limit.

For example, an adventurer could equip two items that each cost 30 Essence, and one that costs 40. An adventurer could not equip three items that each cost 40 Essence, as this would exceed 100 total Essence.

WHAT DOES IT DO?

If you don’t already have a clear idea of what you want an item to do, it can be hard to come up with inspiration. A few easy places to look are class talents, magic from any of the five Magic Sources, and monster abilities. Taking any of these and turning them into a magic item can give your players a fun and unique experience.

Rules.CHAPTER 8 - MONSTER LABORATORY:
The Creature Compendium offers you tons of monsters that you can use to terrorize your heroes. Sometimes, though, you will want a specific monster or a variation on a monster that isn’t quite covered by anything in the Creature Compendium. When this is the case, you can use the guidelines in this chapter to design your own unique monsters.

RESKINNING

Reskinning is the most valuable tool you have at your disposal. Reskinning is the practice of using the mechanics of one monster or spell, but describing it to your players as though an entirely different creature is fighting them. This is an easy way to save yourself some time when prepping a combat. If your party is attacked by dashing highwaymen, you might use the Knight stat block instead of the Bandit stat block, as the stats for Knight better reflect your vision of what a highwayman should be.

TWEAKING

You can also make small modifications to a monster’s stat block to help reskin a little more effectively. Maybe you want an NPC that knows the Fireball spell to do toxic damage instead of fire, or you want to use a Large creature’s stat block as though it were a Medium creature.

For example, a loud, brawny pirate that gets into bar fights and has a terrifying reputation might simply use the stats of a Grash. Decrease his Size to Medium, and increase his INT and CHA to 0 or 1 (adjusting LOG and WILL accordingly). Then describe his climb speed as his skill around rigging, and describe his beak and claw attacks as cutlasses and daggers instead. The Grash’s screech ability might instead be a fearsome bellow that strikes fear into the hearts of all who hear it. By making a couple very small mechanical changes, you have turned a Grash into a pirate.

When reskinning and tweaking a monster, you may overlook a few mechanics that arise in the middle of a combat. If a hero tries to disarm the pirate in the example by knocking their cutlass away, this technically would not be possible because the Grash’s claws and beak are natural weapons. Logically, though, one should be able to disarm a pirate of their cutlass. It’s fine to make such rulings in the spur of the moment as it makes sense for the story and situation.

CUSTOMIZING NPCS

NPCs are some of the easiest creatures to customize. Because NPCs are humanoid, they might undergo some of the same training that your heroes do. Think about the process of creating a hero: you pick a lineage, assign attributes, choose BOP, and gain a talent. You can use any or all of these steps to customize an NPC. For example, you might make a captain of the guard by taking the Guard stat block, giving them the plains elf lineage, making them a born warrior with the guard profession, and giving them one or two talents in the warrior class. This will make that particular guard a bit stronger than your average guard and will impact their fighting style, which can make the NPC seem like an entirely unique creature even if at its base level it is just a modified Guard.

You can also easily change an NPC’s equipment or even give them magic items, but be careful when you do so. If the NPC gets into a lethal confrontation with the heroes, then the heroes will undoubtedly take any magic items that the NPC possessed, so only give the NPC a magic item if you are ready for your heroes to use it.

CUSTOMIZING MONSTERS

Customizing a monster can be a little bit more involved than customizing an NPC. Here are a handful of tools you can use when changing an existing monster to better suit your needs.

MONSTER ARCHETYPES

Once you have picked a monster stat block to modify, consider what kind of archetype might best describe that monster. Archetypes are not strictly mechanical but can help you think about how creatures are represented and how you might modify them. Is the monster you’re modifying a low-health, high damage assassin? Maybe it summons minions to fight on its behalf.

Having identified what archetype the monster fits, you can remove the features that define it as that archetype and give it new features or different HP and defenses based on a new archetype that better fits your vision. Changing a summoner to a beefcake, for example, would entail removing its ability to summon minions and dramatically increasing its HP. You might give a couple of its defenses a small boost as well, and give it the Exploit advanced maneuver so that it can control the battlefield a little more effectively.

MONSTER TRAITS

Many monsters have specific traits that denote certain abilities. Monster traits are listed below, and if you want an easy way to customize a monster, simply swap out the traits that the stat block already has for new options. Changing a Hydra Slime’s Immutable trait to Ethereal dramatically changes the way that the monster feels and functions in a fight.

Monster Trait

Description

Ethereal

Can pass through walls and other barriers and surfaces freely.

Immovable

Cannot be teleported or moved against its will.

Immutable

Cannot have its physical form changed, such as with Cloven Step.

Invisible

A creature with this trait is Unseen and remains Unseen even when under circumstances that would normally end the Unseen condition.

Iron Will

Cannot gain the Frightened or Shaken conditions.

Regen X

At the start of each of its turns, the creature regains HP equal to its Regen number.

Steel Mind

Cannot gain the Charmed or Enthralled conditions.

Unerring Mind

Cannot be tricked by illusions, disguise magic or magical effects, and sees the true form of any shapechanger or polymorphed creature.

Vigilant

Does not suffer any penalties to its AWR while Unconscious.

MYTHIC

Mythic monsters are incredibly challenging to fight. A Mythic monster has the Iron Will and Steel Mind traits. A Mythic monster also is more difficult to kill: if it gains the Helpless condition, it is not reduced to 0 HP when it takes damage. Instead, all damage that it takes is considered critical.

Finally, Mythic monsters do not roll Initiative, but instead act after every 2 characters in Initiative order, making them much more capable of devastating a battlefield.

MONSTER TAGS

Another way to quickly create a custom monster is by mixing and matching monster tags. The monster tags are as follows:

Mundane: beast, humanoid, monstrosity, plant

Planar: avadri, celestial, eldritch, elemental, fae, fiend

Magical: arcane, divine, occult, primal, psionic

Modifying: abominable, constructed, giant, shapechanger, swarm, undead

By giving a monster a different tag, it will interact with some of your heroes’ abilities differently (such as the cleric’s Sense Planar ability). You can also look at other monsters in the Creature Compendium that do have that tag and apply their features to your monster.

For example, if you want to make a biotechnical avadri steed, you might take the stats of a warhorse to start. Change its tag from beast to avadri. Then, look at some similar creatures that have the avadri tag, like the trench abomination. Maybe you want to give your warhorse a similar Rapid Mutation table or the Electric Skin feature.

MCMM

MythCraft Monster Math (MCMM) is the formula that the designers used when creating official monsters for the game. You can use the following tables when creating a monster from scratch, or when checking your redesigned monster against the balance of the monsters in the Creature Compendium. A monster’s typical HP, attributes, simulated AP, and approximate damage per round (DPR) are listed by ML.

Note that these are only benchmarks, not hard and fast rules. Remember a creature’s archetype: a monster that functions as an assassin will have lower max HP and higher DPR than the average for its ML.

ML

ML, or Monster Level, represents how powerful a monster is. You use this to calculate the balance of a combat encounter.

TOTAL STATS

A monster’s total stats is the sum of their STR, DEX, END, AWR, INT, and CHA. For example, a creature with ML 3 might have 2 STR, 0 DEX, 0 END, 3 AWR, 0 INT, and 2 CHA. Like heroes, creatures can have up to a -3 in a stat, and this is especially common among beasts, who typically have -2 or -3 INT.

MAX STAT

A monster’s max stat is the cap on how high a single stat can be. A creature with ML 3 typically would not have more than a +3 in a single stat, while a creature of ML 16 might have as high as a +6. Monsters of specific archetypes might break this rule, but this is uncommon.

HP

A monster’s HP is the recommended maximum HP that a creature of a certain ML would have. This is easy to scale up or down based on how long you want a monster to live.

Minions should have very low maximum HP, while beefcakes might have more HP than their corresponding ML recommends.

AP SIMULATED

AP Simulated is the number of Action Points that the monster is assumed to have. MCs do not track AP for monsters, as it would be very time consuming to attempt this for multiple NPCs and would cause no shortage of headaches. Instead, use the AP Sim’d column to convert AP into Monster Actions.

ARMOR

This is the recommended value of a creature’s AR based on their ML. Tough creatures or humanoids wearing heavy armor might have a higher AR, but this should usually come with some kind of tradeoff, such as a lower number of total stats, reduced speed, or a lower DPR.

ATTACK BONUS

A monster’s recommended attack bonus will correspond to their max stat. A monster that mainly fights with DEX will have the highest possible DEX that it can at that ML, for example.

DPR

DPR, or Damage Per Round, is the amount of damage a monster could do if it attacked as many times as it could on its turn and hit each time, dealing average damage. A soldier of ML 0.5 might have a STR of 2, dealing an average of 5 (1d6+2) damage with its shortsword and being able to attack only once per round. A highly trained soldier of ML 6 might have a STR of 3 and have the ability to attack twice on each of their turns, dealing 6 (1d6+3) damage with each hit. Assassins will obviously deal more damage, and beefcakes, controllers, and summoners will usually deal a little less.

Rules.CHAPTER 9 - EXPLORING ANCERRA:
Ancerra is the planet on which MythCraft’s adventures begin. This chapter offers detailed information on forty-seven nations that occupy Ancerra’s biggest continent, Gathandia. Ancerra has many explorable regions beyond the oceans that surround Gathandia. Indeed, Ancerra has five moons, three of which have breathable atmospheres and vegetation. You should feel free to make up interesting environments for your players to explore, but the information in this chapter will give you plenty of specific material to work with if you run your games on the continent of Gathandia.

THE TEAR

Ancerra’s broad history can be divided into four supereons, each transition into a new supereon marked by some kind of momentous event. The setting for MythCraft’s first adventures is the second supereon.

The first supereon was a prolonged time of enormous planetary natural disasters and rampaging kaijan.

A series of devastating disasters and valiant efforts from humanoids to put an end to the kaijan menace laid the groundwork for civilizations to truly prosper, and a remarkable phenomenon in the sky reflects this monumental change. For generations, the night sky held nothing other than the moons. Murky clouds lay beyond the moons by night and the sun by day. But about eight hundred years ago, this changed. Like a tear in a curtain, a great rend opened in the sky. By day, this is a stretch of sky where the distant clouds are absent, though normal atmospheric clouds might still float through this space. By night, those who look to the sky can see stars for the first time in recorded history. While the clouds that separate Ancerra’s solar system from the Pale still persist, the enormous tear in the sky is filled with the magic of twinkling stars, filling the people of Ancerra with wonder and awe.

NATIONS

AHTEN

An ancient nation that developed along the River Ahten, this region would be terribly inhospitable if not for its mighty water source. The River Ahten flows reliably from a ground spring in the nation’s northwest and follows a predictable seasonal calendar down to the week. It floods every spring, and the water level lowers by a couple feet every fall. The river’s predictability has allowed the nation of Ahten to thrive.

The land, otherwise arid and rocky desert, is a flourishing oasis along the river. Farmers use the predictable seasonal flows to harvest abundant crops, which they use to enhance Ahten’s international economy. This is all overseen by a revered godking.

Academic. Ahten has several prominent universities, the largest of which is in Khamen, the capital. Ahten’s scholars and scientists are quite prestigious, and their universities draw the interest of scholars from across the continent. The headmasters of each university in Ahten are sphinxes who relish the constant access to books and intellectual stimulation.

Aristocratic, Political, and Religious. A theomonarchical dynasty rules Ahten. Each monarch is proclaimed to be a demigod, an emissary between gods and humanoids. When a demigod monarch dies, the nation goes into mourning for thirty days. Monarchs have enormous, elaborate mausoleums and are believed to ascend to full godhood upon their deaths, where they watch over Ahten’s prosperity. Ahten’s current godking, Pharenkan, places a strong focus on the nation’s military given the threat that Roshallan poses.

Mercantile and Trade. In addition to Ahten’s renowned universities, Ahten produces tremendous amounts of crops given its arid climate. It also mines salt and gold from the foothills of the volcanic mountains to its northeast. Furthermore, Ahten has negotiated mining agreements with its neighbor, Gavare, which allows Ahteni miners to operate in Gavare’s territory of the Smoldering Canyon. This supplements Ahten’s economy with magical crafted goods and with ink pigments that contain magical properties.

Militant. Ahten’s soldiers are sturdy and resilient to the extreme heat of the arid summer. Each soldier that graduates from training is tattooed with magical ink pigments from the Smoldering Canyon, enabling them to go for more days at a time without food and water than they otherwise could. Competent on chariots and horseback, and skilled in the ways of desert fighting, they have been able to keep Roshallan at bay.

Social. Ahten’s large agrarian community quickly developed advanced agricultural practices and infrastructure.

The River Ahten floods predictably every year, allowing farmers to utilize floodwaters to their greatest irrigational effect. Because of the river’s predictability, many in Ahten view it as sacred and understand that their society might crumble if the river ever missed a year of its predictable patterns. Ahteni common folk tend to be hospitable towards one another but suspicious of strangers. Most Ahteni are very reverent of their godkings.

Underworld. When one of the Ahteni monarchs dies, they are buried with many riches. This draws irreverent tomb raiders in search of easy loot. The catch, of course, is that many of these tombs are riddled with booby traps and curses designed to repel looters. Furthermore, as repayment for being made headmasters of the universities, Ahteni sphinxes guard the tombs with alacrity.

THREE MAJOR CITIES

Ahten has three major cities, in addition to numerous towns and farming communities along the river. These major cities each house one of Ahten’s most famous universities.

Isirem. Isirem is Ahten’s most populous city, located at the mouth of the River Ahten. Its access to the ocean makes it a valuable trading hub with other nations that engage in maritime trade.

Khalen. Ahten’s capital is located approximately halfway between the river’s spring and its mouth. Khalen boasts enormous monuments to the glory of Ahten and its gods, and the capital is also only a day’s camel ride from the Valley of the Gods. Khalen’s monuments were constructed primarily by golems.

I feel sorry for the mummies of Ahten. They will never experience the freedom of having not a single bodily organ to hinder their clean, pure bone.

-Grim

Set’then. The smallest of Ahten’s three major cities, Set’then is a fortified city that guards the river’s ground springs. If Roshallan were to conquer this city, then they could potentially dam the river, devastating Ahten.

POINTS OF INTEREST

Valley of Gods. The Valley of Gods is where many enormous monuments have been built, along with elaborate mausoleums that have been dug into the side of the rocky hills in the area. Sphinxes and tomb raiders are constantly at war over this territory and the riches hidden deep within.

Smoldering Canyon. The Smoldering Canyon, though primarily within Gavare’s borders, is important to Ahteni culture. The canyon is ripe with valuable minerals, such as mysterious avadrium, primor, and mithril. The canyon’s vegetation also produces pigments that can be used to create magical tattoos. Finally, the Smoldering Canyon produces magical flames and other energies that Ahteni scholars have learned how to contain in stable form.

QUEST IDEAS

  • After a sphinx turned up missing, its colleagues send the heroes to investigate. Unfortunately, the sphinx was murdered; what foul tomb raider possesses such strength? Can the heroes find and stop the thief?
  • The Gavarese want to revoke the rights of the Ahteni miners to keep working in the Smoldering Canyon, but will abandon this threat if the Ahteni send heroes to defeat some mythical monster that has been causing strife for Gavarese mining towns.
  • The River Ahten has flooded - three months early! What could have caused this, and what will it mean for the future of Ahten? Can the heroes investigate and restore the river to its natural flow?
  • The new Ahteni godking has declared that no godking, including himself, has ever truly been divine. This causes tremendous social unrest and many believe that he should be removed from power. Will the heroes help this burgeoning rebellion?
  • Roshallan’s legions are breathing down Set’than’s neck, and Ahten needs every fighter it can muster to protect the springs that feed its mighty river. Will the heroes answer the call?

ANEDONIA

Stretching across a pleasant environment of modest humidity, warm summers, and mild rainy winters, Anedonia is a federation of city-states that share the same cultural practices, holidays, and religious beliefs, though each city-state has different governing systems and economic strengths. The Anedonian islands are rocky but temperate, allowing pastoral culture to flourish alongside orchards of olives and citrus.

The Anedonian city-states operate independently of one another in most instances and have waged war on one another at various points throughout history. However, the whole of Anedonia has rallied together whenever they feel that their way of life faces existential threat, and when united in such fashion they are a tremendous force to be reckoned with. Even the mighty Empire of Roshallan has been unable to subjugate Anedonia due to the Anedonians’ fierce loyalty to their nation above the differences of their individual states.

Religious. Anedonians primarily worship the Ashyidir and Stravon Conclaves of the Archfae and have spun elaborate mythologies around these deities. Although many of these stories never actually occurred, the way that the deities are depicted in these stories is reasonably accurate. Each Anedonian city-state has one patron deity but pays homage to all deities out of these Conclaves.

Social. Anedonian society revolves around free-market maritime traders. Many of Anedonia’s city-states are island nations, so in addition to pastoral and orchard cultivation, the city-states also thrive on a fishing industry. Anedonians are very hospitable to those from any other Anedonian city-state unless they are actively at war with that state. They are generally courteous but suspicious of foreigners.

Underworld. It has not acquired great power yet, but a criminal empire has taken root in Anedonia and is working to extend its influence to every city-state. The criminal empire aims to unite the states into a formal nation with the crime lords as the new oligarchs.

CITY-STATES OF NOTE

Anedonia’s three most prominent city-states are described in a little more detail below, but this is only three out of a couple dozen city-states that are part of the Anedonian federation.

Sethan. The most economically influential of Anedonia’s city-states, Sethan occupies a large island near Anedonia’s mainland coast. The Sethan Academy is the most prestigious in the world, drawing scholars from the whole world to teach their disciplines. Sethan is ruled using an elected senate. In times of crisis, the other city-states of Anedonia will rally behind Sethan as the effective capital of all the city-states.

I dream of one day learning from the musicians in the Sethan Academy! Their pentatonic compositions are effervescent.

-Flanagan

Taspar. Taspar is the largest city-state on Anedonia’s mainland, and the closest to the Roshallani border. It is an autocratic city-state that trains its citizens to be soldiers from the time they are only four years old. This produces some of the toughest, most calloused soldiers in all Gathandia and has prevented Roshallan from gaining a foothold in Anedonia. While Taspar and Sethan have strenuous philosophical disagreements, they respect one another’s accomplishments and view each other as steadfast allies. Taspar’s King Lendonar has proven a mighty military commander and Roshallan has yet to make any headway on conquering Anedonia due to Lendonar’s efforts.

Terec. Terec has a much smaller population than Sethan and Taspar, and is far from the third most populous city-state. It is, however, the third most notable in terms of its contributions to Anedonian society. Situated on a large island deeper into the Inner Sea, Terec possesses deep mines rich in many minerals, including the mystical minerals known as Avadrium and Mithril. Terec’s deep mines have entire towns in their crossroads, but the still unexplored caverns beneath this island are riddled with all manner of dangerous beasts.

QUEST IDEAS

  • Terec’s merchant leadership have asked the heroes to clear out some terrible beasts that lurk in the lower stretches of caverns that Terec wishes to begin mining.
  • Sethan has attracted the interest of a scholar from Getar who wishes for the heroes to protect them in the journey across the Inner Sea.
  • Taspar has come under threat from Roshallan, and they are looking for any competent soldiers to take up arms and help reclaim a tactically advantageous set of foothills.

BETAAL

A small nation that makes its home on the tops of several of the Cloudpiercer Mountains, Betaal’s size in no way reflects its significance. Its people are tough, innovative, and capable of surviving with quite little. The Betaalese are also held to be generous and hospitable with foreigners, although few ever reach Betaal’s highest cities in the peaks of its tallest mountains.

Academic. Each of Betaal’s towns has a monastery where scholars, clergy, and mystics can study or meditate. These monasteries focus much more on the spiritual aspects of the humanoid experience than on traditional academic topics, although Betaal’s two largest cities do have large libraries as well.

Aristocratic and Political. Betaalese society rejects the idea of a ruling elite and believe that those capable of shepherding other people’s souls should do so on both a spiritual and political level. As such, Betaal’s religious leaders - the Prabi - are also its political leaders. If such a leader ever displays an exorbitant lifestyle, they are removed from their order, as asceticism is one of their central tenets.

Mercantile and Trade. Betaal has little in the way of natural resources, other than yaks and snow. Betaal exports both wool and water in abundance, and the dry nation of Kandiff regularly buys water from Betaal. Betaal also exports philosophy, fictional literature, and artistic works, though they must first import dyes and other mediums for these artworks from other nations. Betaal imports raw and finished materials, along with foodstuffs, from any nation that they can reach for trade. They generally trade with Kandiff, Noord, and Doshairiel.

Militant. Taking life is heavily frowned upon in Betaal, which is generally a highly pacifistic nation. When Betaal is attacked, mystics and psions will use their telekinetic powers to cause avalanches or illusory spectacles that will dissuade aggressors from attempting to take Betaal.

Religious. The Prabi practice extreme asceticism. When they are not legislating or counseling their constituents, they often meditate. Many are known to be capable of astral projection and other great psionic powers, and they purport to have spoken directly with representatives of the Celestial Council. It is believed that when a Betaalese monk is chosen to lead a town, they are invited into a psionic mind palace that has been around for thousands of years and contains the wisdom of every Prabi that came before.

One of the Prabi visited me when I was meditating. I have been encouraged to climb the mountain and seek out answers atop the crest of Tapsankad. The journey is long, but one day I will make it.

-Knack

Social. Like the monks that lead or train to lead the nation, many of the Betaalese common folk also practice asceticism, though not to the degree practiced by the monks. Most commoners do not see the need for any wealth beyond enough food and shelter for their families, and perhaps some entertaining books or games to pass the cold, dark nights. Betaalese are hospitable to foreign travelers and will usually offer guidance through the steep and treacherous mountains.

Underworld. Shinus are independently operating cells of skilled assassins that wear folded cloth armor, allowing them to approach their victims silently. Most underworld activity in Betaal is performed by Shinus. A small group of highly skilled Shinus, operating outside the purview of the theocratic rulers of Betaal, will infiltrate and destabilize nations that they think might threaten Betaal. Some of these Shinus also become mercenaries, selling their specialized services to any with enough coin. By both taking life and hoarding wealth, Betaalese Shinus are antithetical to the teachings of the official leaders.

TAPSANKAD

The oldest Betaalese city, Tapsankad is nestled just beneath the highest peak in Betaal. The peak of the mountain is left bare as it is a holy site where monks go to engage in astral projection and, when the time comes, to transcend beyond this world. Tapsankad is a city rich with ancient history, having been founded before the World-Quake.

Within the city, Tapsankad contains many residences, some modest markets, and curated parks lush with cold-weather plants. The citizens of Tapsankad hold festivals on each solstice and each equinox, which are the only days each year where hedonism is not viewed in contempt.

QUEST IDEAS

  • The heroes must climb the Cloudpiercer Mountains to reach Tapsankad. There, they must entreat the monks to send more water and spare Kandiff from a terrible drought.
  • One of Betaal’s towns has been attacked by an icy monster. The Prabi ask the heroes to go defeat the monster and liberate its citizens.
  • Tension is mounting between the Prabi and the Shinus as the Noords threaten to conquer Betaal. The heroes must decide who they agree with and seek to broker a peace or, short of that, throw their support behind one faction or the other.

BISHAL

The wide open plains and arid steppes of Bishal are home to several large tribes, all of whom share a general culture but who are often at war with one another.

Each Bishalian tribe follows a nomadic lifestyle, leading their massive horse herds to fresh pastures or following the herds of bison that they use for food, tools, and clothing.

Aristocratic and Political. Each tribal lord is responsible for their own tribe’s actions but has little interest in the other tribes beyond occasional trades or skirmishes. On the rare occasions that multiple tribal lords feel that their entire nation is threatened, then the lords will come together where the two major rivers in Bishal join together into one. There, the lords will negotiate working together and for how long they are bound to do so. The largest and most belligerent Bishalian tribal lord is named Tilion, and he has made quite a name for himself and his tribe as a military power to be reckoned with.

Mercantile and Trade. Bishalians typically trade internally instead of internationally. They use clay from the riverbeds to make pottery, and use every part of bison and other game animals to make food and various tools or clothes. Usually, if they consider trading with a foreign town or merchant caravan, they will instead just raid it.

Militant. Bishalians make excellent cavaliers, and many Bishalian warriors are more at home on horseback than they are on foot. Capable of firing shortbows while riding, a Bishalian tribe’s warriors can conduct quick and brutal raids on the towns of other nations that border their territory.

Religious and Social. The people of Bishal tend to be very religious and believe horses to be sacred animals. They worship A’rl’ng, the great steed of the Shibmar Conclave of the Archfae, as a guiding patron. Most Bishalians believe in a cycle of reincarnation where when a humanoid dies, they are reborn as a horse, and when a horse dies, they are reborn as a humanoid. People generally hold that Centaurs are the reincarnations of especially brave or honorable humanoids or steeds.

THE RIVERFLOW

Where Bishal’s two rivers come together, there is a tranquil set of hills known as the Riverflow. This is where Bishalian lords come together when they need to confer on a national level.

The waters of the Riverflow run cold and sweet. I’m not much a fan of Bishalian warmongering, but the Riverflow, at least, is a place of peace.

-Chauncey

QUEST IDEAS

  • In his old age, a cruel Bishalian lord has grown militant and violent against the other tribes. The heroes must put an end to his rampage.
  • Bishal is threatened by some external force. The heroes must travel to each lord in turn and convince them to travel to the Riverflow and establish a consensus.

BRIDGEMOOR

Bridgemoor is an economically powerful independent city-state built entirely on a massive bridge that spans the Great Chasm. As the only other ways to cross the chasm involve going hundreds of miles north to circumvent it or climbing down, navigating across its monster-riddled trenches, and climbing back up, Bridgemoor has made a fortune off of merchants and travelers that use the city-state as passage over the Chasm.

Bridgemoor is just large enough that a full day’s travel will not quite get one across the chasm, forcing travelers to spend extra coin in one of Bridgemoor’s many inns and taverns. Through this calculated design and by exacting a small toll on every traveler, Bridgemoor thrives.

Bridgemoor is governed by an oligarchy known as the Meritocrats. Selected once every ten years, prospective Meritocrats must first pass a test proving their scholastic and economic knowledge, and then each former Meritocrat picks their successor. This has generally led to rampant nepotism with very rare exceptions.

Academic. Bridgemoor has a large university and scholastic achievements are widely celebrated throughout the city-state. Those with more formal education are more likely to be rewarded by Meritocrats or become one themselves, so anyone who can afford to send their children to the university will do so.

Mercantile and Trade. Bridgemoor is a thriving mercantile state. Due to a high volume of travelers and merchants flowing into and through the city-state, Bridgemoor has one of the strongest economies in its region. It trades especially frequently with Nalathesh and Kendaria as it connects the two nations, but merchants from other nations will stop in Bridgemoor on their way to or from Kendaria and Nalathesh as well.

Bridgemoor is vital to the health of the Great Chasm nations. Without it, trade patterns would be thrown into horrible disarray.

-Marcus

Militant. Bridge Knight Commander Ser Kellion Blacksky maintains strict discipline in the streets of Bridgemoor. Under his guidance, the Bridge Knights have become more disciplined and competent than they have ever been historically. Few in number, the Bridge Knights could not wage war on a neighboring country, but they could defend Bridgemoor indefinitely or until food and water run out.

Political. The Meritocrats oversee legislation and appoint the Bridge Knight Commander and the Master Magister. These two figures, in turn, will appoint their subordinate administrators (Bridge Knight Captains and Magisters, respectively) to maintain executive and judicial law within the city.

Religious. Bridgemoor does not have an official religion, and each citizen is encouraged to pursue their own beliefs. Several temples dedicated to specific pantheons or tenets can be found throughout Bridgemoor, along with unaffiliated houses of worship that offer a quiet, contemplative space for any belief system.

Social. Bridgemoor has a very diverse culture. Folk from Nalathesh and Kendaria make up most of Bridgemoor’s citizens, but some traders from lands beyond decided to settle in Bridgemoor as well, leading to a confluence of many beliefs. It’s not uncommon for there to be at least two festivals in a given month due to the wide spectrum of cultures and religions and their respective celebratory events.

Underworld. Bridgemoor has no shortage of white-collar criminals that use any loophole in the city-state’s tax system and mercantile economy to line their own pockets with a little more silver and gold. Overt crime is uncommon thanks to Ser Kellion’s iron discipline, but cult activity lurks in the sewers and storage cellars beneath the streets. Called the Underbridge Cult, these miscreants are a countercultural movement looking to prove how meaningless and absurd “Meritocracy” truly is. Among other things, they try to summon fiends from Inferno to wreak havoc in the city.

POINTS OF INTEREST

The Great Chasm. The Great Chasm stretches for thousands of miles from north to south along the eastern half of Gathandia.

Bridgemoor spans one of its narrowest points, connecting Nalathesh to Kendaria. Intrepid explorers have discovered crypts full of strange technology from an ancient civilization, but some have also met their grizzly end at the hands of equally strange beasts that lurk in the Chasm’s endless caves.

QUEST IDEAS

  • The Meritocrats are preparing to choose their heirs, and some merchants want the heroes to help fix the results.
  • The Underbridge Cult has successfully summoned a Bonewraith, who lurks in the sewers and sends Zombies to terrorize the city-state.
  • An explorer wants to hire the heroes as protection as they venture into the chasm.
  • Ser Kellion Blacksky pursues authoritarian control of the streets in response to cult activity, but this harms Bridgemoor’s economy. How can the heroes step in and fix this?

BUYLEIST

For many generations, Buyleist was significantly weaker than its neighbor nation, Unjaarn. Buyleist’s rulers lived under the constant shadow of fear that Unjaar would decide to invade them or cut them off from international trade, and unfortunately this did come to pass a couple generations ago.

As it turns out, this was a mistake on Unjaar’s part. Buyleist made an alliance with Vel, and Vel’s nefarious mages sowed discord in Unjaar’s internal affairs. This eventually led to a complete schism within Unjaar, which resulted in the nation splitting in two. Now, the two split nations - Unjaar and Vadan - are both smaller and weaker than Buyleist, allowing the Buyleistians to flex their muscles in the region.

Academic. Buyleist is building its first major university and hopes to attract scholars from other nations to help get the educational program off the ground. Vel’s Mages of the Beach are more than willing to assist in this process.

Aristocratic and Political. Buyleist rejects the notion of aristocracy or a caste system wholesale. Instead, their governing body is a representative democracy elected by any citizen who makes a large enough annual salary to be offered a ballot. While these elections offer the illusion of choice, the Mages of the Beach from Vel are really in charge and make sure that each “election” actually promotes a Buyleistian who will do exactly what the Mages instruct.

There’s a stink about Buyleist. The folk purport to be free, but Vel plays the nation like a fiddler plays her strings.

-Lyla

Mercantile and Trade. Buyleist exports many dye pigments, spices, and foodstuffs unique to the swamp delta.

While Unjaar and Vadan also export many of the same materials, Buyleist’s economic advantage allows them to undersell their competition.

Militant. The military in Buyleist is medium-sized and quite competent. It could almost certainly defeat Vadan or Unjaar independently, but if the two made an alliance against Buyleist, then Buyleist might be in trouble.

Religious. While Buyleistians can practice any religion that they wish, doing so is generally discouraged. The governing body reminds Buyleist’s citizenry that they are in such times of prosperity because of the wisdom and generosity of the Mages of the Beach, and it is truly the Mages who should be venerated.

Social. Citizens of Buyleist are encouraged to pursue the careers and hobbies that most interest them. This keeps Buyleistians generally content and preoccupied with their own ventures, though some political dissidents speak out against their nation’s alliance with Vel.

Underworld. The most fervent political opponents to Vel have formed a covert rebellion. This has not yet developed into violence, although many who are aware of the resistance movement think that it’s only a matter of time.

SELMORT

The capital of Buyleist is the fortified stilt city of Selmort. The city is built in tiers, with wide, flat barges holding apartments where the poor live. Elevated platform houses, suspended over the swamp on stilts and connected by rope bridges, are home to the middle class and to the marketplaces.

A large bastion built of stone and clay is home to Buyleist’s national governing body. In the fetid swamps behind this bastion, a small M’l’ykkri has buried itself in the water. Political dissidents that upset the Mages of the Beach often wind up as snacks for this horrible monster.

POINTS OF INTEREST

Swamplands of the Great Chasm. A humid tropical swamp spreads across a vast river delta on the southern end of the Great Chasm. Many small islands blanket this region, separated by shallow waters that would be treacherous for large boats. A wide variety of natural flora and fauna mix with the strange minerals and ancient technologies buried deep in the Chasm; as a result, unnatural land formations and horrible monsters lurk outside of the stilted cities and villages that speckle the swamplands. “Travel by day, and you’ll be safe; travel by night, you’ll get a fright” is a common rhyme in these lands, and children dare one another to explore the swamps outside their settlements.

QUEST IDEAS

  • The heroes get accused of political malfeasance and risk becoming a M’l’ykkri snack if they cannot escape.
  • The heroes might get caught up in the three-way trade war between Buyleist, Vadan, and Unjaar. They will have to carefully evaluate who they support.
  • The Mages of the Beach promise great rewards to the heroes if they will find and quash a burgeoning rebellion.
  • Illegal drug trade is running rampant in the swamps beneath the stilted districts of Selmort. The heroes must find and put an end to these trades.

CHEE

The forest nation of Chee used to be much larger and more prosperous. Originally, Chee was part of Chehozran, but after a short civil war they split along the mountain range that separates the two regions. Chee never recovered economically from the civil war, struggling to make an international name for itself. Before it was able to achieve any notable successes, Roshallan annexed Chee.

Academic. Chee has no major academies. All of its small schools that teach basic educational subjects are managed by Roshallan.

Aristocratic and Political. Chee is governed by lesser kings assigned to the region from Roshallan. The Chee folk have no say in their own governmental practices.

Mercantile and Trade. Chee’s forests produce a bounty of foodstuffs and timber, along with colorful pigments. The coast teems with fish, and Deeprock’s shipyards manufacture powerful shallow and deep water ships.

Chee’s fine shipyard economy does not erase the tragedy of her erasure by a tyrant’s hand.

-Finneas

Military. Chee has no military; its armed forces were completely defeated and disbanded by Roshallan.

Religious. In the privacy of their own homes, most Chee folk keep alive the traditions of their ancestors. Like the Chehozran, the Chee believe that one day the kaijan of old will return: some will be benevolent, and many will be tyrannical. They pray that the kaijan who return to the nation of Chee will strive to protect, rather than to destroy.

Social. While many Chee folk wish that they could run their own country instead of being controlled by Roshallan, they also recognize that Roshallan’s powerful military offers them great security. Most folk of Chee simply go about their lives, helping out their friends when they can and avoiding strangers.

Underworld. Some nationalistic Chee folk have taken it upon themselves to overthrow Roshallan. While the more rational among these rebels simply try to disrupt Roshallan’s presence in Chee’s territory, some ambitious rebels intend to overthrow the entire Roshallani empire.

DEEPROCK

Chee’s only major city, Deeprock, is micromanaged by Roshallan. It has a fortified palace where a Roshallani regional king oversees the nation of Chee. A strong military presence keeps the peace, and Deeprock’s enormous shipyards produce large, powerful naval vessels at a rapid rate, which Roshallan uses to conquer other nations that border the Inner Sea.

QUEST IDEAS

  • Roshallan hires the heroes to head into Chee and put down a developing rebellion. The rebels might also approach the heroes and ask them to help chase Roshallan out of the nation. Caught between the two parties’ desires, the heroes must weigh their morals and their desire for wealthy compensation.
  • Roshallan will have unparalleled naval superiority if they can finish building their flagship, the Thunderhead. Chee’s rebels want the heroes to help them sabotage the vessel so that it will sink once many hundreds of Roshallani soldiers are on deck and out in the deep sea.

CHEHOZRAN

Once an enormous forest nation that spread from the Inner Sea to the oceans west of Gathandia, Chehozran is now half the size it once was. Generations ago, pragmatic leaders split the northeastern half of the nation off into the new kingdom of Chee in an effort to consolidate resources in two locations. Chee has since been conquered by Roshallan.

Chehozran remains independent of Roshallan, but Chehozran continually adds additional fortifications and trained soldiers to its border as it anticipates invasion from the aggressive nation at any point.

Academic. Chehozran has little to offer in the way of formal schooling. The elderly in towns throughout the nation will often teach the young, and those who desire often travel to Pash to receive additional formal education.

Aristocratic and Political. Chehozran does not have an aristocracy besides the royal family. Following the tradition of primogeniture, each eldest child becomes the next monarch. Besides the monarchy, other officials and representatives are democratically elected. This preserves the continuity of leadership at the highest levels of government while allowing the people’s voices to be heard through local elections.

Mercantile and Trade. Chehozran produces sizable quantities of lumber, game, vegetables, minerals, clay, pigments, and fine art made using such materials. They primarily trade within the borders of their own nation but have open trade agreements with Pash.

Militant. The military in Chehozran is large, skilled, and disciplined. They do not have the strongest iron or the most modern weaponry, but they know their terrain exceptionally well. Thus far, they have held off all preliminary Roshallani scouting parties.

Religious. Looking to the ancient past, the Chehozranese worship the kaijans of old. They believe that one day, the kaijans will return and will scour the world again. While this will cause much devastation, Chehozranese prophets claim that some among the kaijan will be protectors that shelter the faithful from the wrath of the other kaijans.

Social. The folk of Chehozran trust their own and will provide for one another. Shelter and food are considered communal, and few are ever left wanting. This hospitable practice is generally afforded to Pashans as well. This courtesy does not, however, extend to other foreigners, who are treated with suspicion if not outright hostility.

Underworld. Given that Chehozran is focused on the threat of Roshallan, there are a handful of opportunistic gangs. A crime syndicate also extends throughout Chehozran, exploiting the air of fear.

I wouldn’t be surprised if Felson Weskh’s network extended as far west as Chehozran.

-Avery

YIRISK

Chehozran’s capital city, Yirisk, is near the head of the Chehozran River in a wide valley between the two southern prongs of the mountain range that embraces Chehozran’s northern regions. Yirisk’s riverside docks frequently house Pashan merchant vessels. In preparation for the worst case scenario, Chehozranese officials have been preparing a contingency in the event of Roshallani invasion. A fortified network of caverns in the mountains could hold most of Chehozran’s population for several years in the event of a protracted siege.

QUEST IDEAS

  • The Roshallani have finally invaded Chehozran. The heroes must help civilians evacuate and reach the fortifications at Yirisk, doing whatever they can to forestall Roshallani advances.
  • The excavators designing fortified caverns have come across a nest of ancient monsters. The heroes must defeat these monsters to make room for additional wartime bunkers.
  • Parsors with a twisted sense of humor have dammed the Chehozran River, blocking their economic ties to Pash. The heroes need to convince the Parsors to remove the dam.

CONSTEL

Constel is a nation of mixed opinions and mixed peoples. Once the heart of a much larger and prosperous monarchy, now a small and economically struggling democracy, Constel has many traditional folk and many who challenge the old ways of living.

Constel’s chief export is timber from the Old Forest. Loggers have deforested Constel so rapidly that it is now more plains and pasture than forest, much the opposite of what it was less than a hundred years ago. Traditionalists warn that this will be Constel’s doom: the Old Forest is strange and unforgiving of such sins. Progressives, however, argue that this was a necessary step to get Constel on its feet. The destruction of the Old Forest is largely what gave Constel the financial means to establish its university, which attracts intellectuals from the world over.

Me? I’m not much one for tradition, but yeah, mess with the Old Forest and the Old Forest will mess back.

-Dungrel

Academic. Lentira has a large university with scholars that specialize in legal theory and philosophy. The University of Constel attracts many students from many nations, leading to a vast dissemination of ideas. Headmaster Edwardton keeps in very close contact with the governing representatives of Constel.

Aristocratic and Political. After the ancient civil war that led to the split with Kendaria, Constel underwent a tremendous governmental change and became a democracy. Each town and city sends a representative to Lentira, where the representatives negotiate legislation on behalf of their constituents.

Mercantile and Trade. Constel exports tremendous amounts of timber and finished wooden products, along with clay goods and philosophical ideas. Constel trades locally with both Kendaria and Forsten and conducts maritime trade with Derk.
