Underworld. There are individuals in every caste who are willing to break convention. A thinly spread but well organized network of smugglers help people cross the border to Vadan when desired.

NELIDI

The capital of Unjaarn is a massive city spread across several small islands in a shallow area of the swamplands. With a population of over three million, Nelidi is the largest city on the east of the Cloudpiercer Range.

The largest Brahma temple is in Nelidi, along with multiple elite schools and the palace from which the Nelida run their nation.

POINTS OF INTEREST

Swamplands of the Great Chasm. See Buyleist for more information.

QUEST IDEAS

  • The Nelida do not want to risk the lives of Duskiran soldiers on a mission to slay a deadly swamp beast, so they send the heroes instead.
  • A small group of Likishuan families want to move to Vadan and ask the heroes to protect them on their journeys.
  • A member of the Nelida privately confers with the heroes and conspires to abolish the caste system.
  • A beloved Brahma has gone missing. When the heroes venture into the swamp, they find that they have teleported to the Everwilds.

VADAN

A network of swampy bayous and steamy marshlands, Vadan recently seceded from its southern neighbor, Unjaarn. Although they share a culture and belief system, the Vadanians differ strongly from the Unjaarni in their approach to governance. While Unjaarn is a rigid caste system, Vadan runs on an aggressively capitalist government. Many folk from Vadan would prefer to live in Unjaarn, and vice versa, but the border between the two nations is a dangerous and often violent region.

Academic. Vadan’s capital has a large university, but very few scholars reside in it year-round, which makes it difficult for the university to grow.

Mercantile and Trade. Vadan exports food, spices of many varieties, and clay to neighboring nations. They also mine the Great Chasm to their north and export gems and rare metals. Vadan is locked in a trade war with Unjaarn, trying to lock down trade partnerships with other nations and block Unjaarn from doing so.

Militant. The Vadanian military is tremendously patriotic but poorly trained. Having recently secured independence from Unjaarn, the Vadanian military now struggles to bring discipline and structure to its ranks. In skirmishes with Unjaarni, the Vadanians usually win in battles that transpire in thick underbrush but lose if the battle takes place on an open lake or plain.

Political and Social. Vadan has a very free-market approach to governance. Those who seize on risky opportunities might flourish or might end up being left out to dry. There is no social safety net other than the generosity of neighbors, and many would rather ensure that they get ahead instead of spending time offering charity and risking getting dragged down themselves. Because of Vadan’s highly stressful and volatile system, some Vadanians emigrate to Unjaarn, where the rigid caste system provides stability.

Their economy has totally run amok, and there is poverty everywhere you look. I’m not sure that Unjaarn has the answers either, but in Vadan, thousands of people go to bed hungry every night. Something has to change.

-Chauncey

Religious. Vadanians largely share the same religious beliefs as the Unjaarni. There are many hundreds of gods, and individual communities may pay special homage to specific deities. As in Unjaarn, three specific gods from the Shibmar Conclave of the Archfae hold special prominence: Tamat, Khailain, and Immort.

Underworld. Many independent smugglers help transport people south into Unjaarn when they wish. Some of the most successful smugglers know which Unjaarni officials can be bribed to help secure a higher caste for the immigrant.

VADAN

The capital of Vadan, by the same name, was the third-largest city in Unjaarn before the secession. While most of the citizens of the capital strongly prefer Vadan’s system of governance to Unjaarn’s, there are clear signs of poverty in Vadan’s mucky alleyways, shantytowns, and glamorous fenced-off neighborhoods.

The capital is home of Vadan’s only university, which is also where the governmental buildings are located. Vadan is run by a parliament of the fifteen wealthiest citizens of the country. This is reassessed every half-year, which in theory would allow for a quickly rotating door of legislators. In practice, a couple dozen wealthy elites spend most of their time running their businesses or passing legislation that benefit their business or hurt their rivals, ensuring that they remain in the legislative shortlist.

POINTS OF INTEREST

Swamplands of the Great Chasm. See Buyleist for more information.

QUEST IDEAS

  • Some impoverished and embittered citizens want to start a revolution against the parliament and ask the heroes to lead them.
  • A smuggler needs the heroes to bribe an administrator in Unjaarn to help get some Vadanian immigrants into the southern country.
  • A beloved member of the community has gone missing in the deep bayou. Their friends hope that the heroes can find them.
  • Rumor has it that the parliament plans on passing legislation that will make Vadan a monarchy. Rival merchants ask the heroes to prevent this at any cost.

VAENYTH

In a word, Vaenyth is cruel. Its jagged shale hills are full of dangerous monsters and deep chasms. Its sparse woodlands are equally perilous. Vaenyth’s mountain range plays havoc on weather patterns and the nation suffers from seasonal typhoons, hailstorms, and tornadoes.

Vaenyth’s population is a humanoid incarnation of this turbulent cruelty. With a savage governing system and near-constant civil wars, Vaenyth is a nation of anger and blood.

Academic. Vaenythan culture places little value in formal education. One’s capacity to perform their job well is usually all that matters.

Aristocratic and Political. With perhaps the most bizarre governing system in Gathandia, Vaenyth chooses their new monarch once every ten years. When they do so, each noble family who wishes to make a bid for the monarchy sends forth a champion to fight on their behalf. These champions each battle to the death in a massive arena riddled with traps and captured monsters. The sole surviving champion is ritually slaughtered, and the new monarch bathes in their blood before ascending to the throne for the next ten years.

So, I’ve been known to summon the occasional demon, but even I think that the Vaenythans have all lost their bloody minds.

-Dungrel

Mercantile and Trade. Vaenyth generally does not trade with other nations, with the exception of Pash. Vaenyth produces iron ore, stone from quarries, and animal and plant byproducts, which primarily circulate within Vaenyth’s own economy.

Militant. Vaenyth’s military is quite strong and well-equipped but lacks discipline and cohesion. More often than not, Vaenythan military contingents go to war with one another than with common enemies.

Religious. Vaenythans primarily worship the Exiles and the Archfiends of Inferno. They believe that the most powerful deities are those who can survive in the least comfortable circumstances. This power then translates into understanding and knowledge. Vaenythan priestly rituals often involve animal slaughter and occasionally include humanoid sacrifice.

Social and Underworld. Criminal activity is standard in any Vaenythan settlement. Cheating on taxes, mugging a neighbor in a back alley, petty burglary, and vengeance-driven murder are all commonplace. The only law of the land is the proclamations of the monarch, and even then, these are more suggestions than hard and fast decrees.

BLOODSTONE

The capital citadel of Vaenyth and the death-soaked throne of the monarchy is Bloodstone. This is a massive fortress carved from stone and reinforced with an iron-Arcanium alloy developed by ancient mystics long ago and since forgotten to history. A hundred thousand soldiers have been turned away by a mere eighty that held Bloodstone, the legends say.

POINTS OF INTEREST

Floating Islands. The floating islands that stretch as far south as Pash’s Great Bay soar high above Vaenyth. Given their disinterest in scholarly pursuits, Vaenythans have no idea that Arcanium and Primor could be mined from these islands in abundance.

QUEST IDEAS

  • Vaenyth’s rulers ask the heroes to infiltrate Pash and siphon large sums of money back into Vaenyth’s own pockets.
  • The monarch of Vaenyth asks the heroes to find a way to reach the floating islands and crash them down to the ground so that they can be studied.
  • Vaenyth has decided to hold a special electoral battle with teams of champions. The heroes have been chosen as one such team.

VALSTROM

In the shadowy Thunderhead Vale to the east of the Cloudpiercer Range, the kingdom of Valstrom sprawls along the Thunderhead River. With the Cloudpiercers to Valstrom’s west and north, and the Hadla mountains to its east, Valstrom catches a tremendous amount of rain and humidity from the Kozia Rainforest. Valstrom’s summers are hot and humid, its winters chilly and often snowy. Its falls are vibrant with bright leaves, its springs with bright flowers.

Valstrom’s charming seasons have drawn many peoples over the generations, and in the clearings of the subtropical forests its ancient towns are steeped in layers of history. Most towns and all of Valstrom’s cities are heavily timber-based, with log buildings and wooden tiles or thatched roofs. A few fortified buildings, such as the town watch and the lord or lady’s castle, are predominantly classical stone castles.

Generations ago, Shadradoth split away from Valstrom as an independent nation. When the king passed away, his chief advisor became king regent, but refused to abdicate when the late king’s daughter came of age. The resulting civil war tore the kingdom in half, and Princess Shadra, unable to claim the throne from Rehan Jehoram, had to make do with her half of the kingdom. The Jehorams continue their rule to this day.

A pleasant natural environment mixed with dozens of tragic stories. I may be here a while.

-Flanagan

Academic. Valstrom’s larger towns usually have some kind of academy or university. Some of these are in a state of disuse, but many still have thriving libraries, research facilities, and classes.

Aristocratic and Political. A classical feudal society has been implemented in Valstrom for all of its recorded history. Mayors report to counts and countesses, who report to dukes and duchesses, who report to the monarch. The monarch’s eldest child assumes the monarchy after their parent passes away or abdicates the throne.

Mercantile and Trade. Valstrom has had its share of unrest, but over many generations it has proven to be a reliable trade partner. Its neighboring land nations include Sozein and Tafunga to the south, and Falth, Nalathesh, and Husk to the north. Valstrom maintains a robust trade relationship with Shadradoth despite their historical tensions. Merchants competent in mountain passes will also trade with Hadla to the east.

Militant. Valstrom maintains its classical feudal system in how its military functions. Each mayor has a small local army that keeps the peace in and around their settlement. Counts and countesses also have small armies, and have the political capital to levy the armies of the mayors that live within their territories. Dukes and duchesses can likewise levy any army under the control of any count in their province, and the monarch can of course levy any duke’s or duchess’s forces when the need arises.

Religious. Valstromians traditionally worship the Celestial Council, seeing its leaders as the gods that bless or curse them in accordance with their piety, or lack thereof. Any settlement will have at least a small temple with an altar dedicated to these gods, and the larger cities compete with one another to have the grandest, most beautiful temple out of any Valstromian society.

Social. Most Valstromians are content with their feudal hierarchy, but some are discontent with it. Many of the peasantry have their basic needs met: food, drink, comfortable shelter, and basic leisure activities. These peasants often don’t care whether they get ahead in life or not, so long as their needs remain fulfilled. Some of the peasantry, by contrast, think that the feudal system is out of date and should have been abolished long ago.

Many counts and dukes also feel tremendous discontent. Having achieved success, but knowing that the dukes will always have more power and influence, counts and countesses often lose sleep scheming about how they might get ahead in the political system. Dukes and duchesses, in turn, often fret about maintaining the power they have.

Underworld. Valstrom’s traditional feudal structure leaves ample room for crime syndicates to operate in the shadows, as details often get lost in the chain of command from mayor to monarch and back. Notable syndicates include the Twice Strikes, the Hoods, and the Galepiercers (see Shadradoth for information on each syndicate).

STORMVALE

The capital and oldest city in Valstrom is Stormvale. Stormvale is an expansive city that extends from the banks of the Thundervale River up into the foothills of the Hadla Mountains. Parts of Stormvale have fallen into utter disrepair and are almost more forest than city at this point, but much of the city - especially that closest to the river - thrives as a bustling metropolis.

The royal castle overlooks the river and is surrounded by an artificial moat connected to the river. On the mainland, the Stormvale University holds classrooms and dormitories full of intellectuals.

The Stormvale Cathedral is also a marvel of architectural and artistic achievement, and the religious among the nation often travel to behold the wondrous stained glass depictions of the various members of the Celestial Council.

POINTS OF INTEREST

Cloudpiercers. See Shadradoth for information on the Cloudpiercer Range and the tallest mountain in the known world.

Thundervale River. The Valstromians and Shadradothans have built a shared city at the base of a magical waterfall in the Thundervale River. See Shadradoth for more information on this remarkable place.

QUEST IDEAS

  • Valstrom faces another heirship crisis, and various nobles across the kingdom make their power plays. The heroes must interact with these nobles and determine who they wish to support.
  • The entire Valstromian/Shadradothan town at the base of the magic waterfall has vanished. Perhaps it’s in the Everwilds.
  • Monsters have been reported in the overgrown neighborhoods of Stormvale. Will the heroes free the city from these menaces?
  • Adventurers and a famous noble have gone missing after boasting that they could climb the Great Cloudpierce, the tallest mountain in the world. Another noble calls upon the heroes to mount a rescue mission.

VEL

A tiny but powerful city-state clinging to the craggy beaches of Gathandia’s southeast peninsula, Vel is ruled by a kleptocratic oligarchy known as the Mages of the Beach. The Mages control every aspect of life in Vel and their powerful diviners keep a watchful eye on the city-state, ready to quash dissent at a moment’s notice. Common laborers and merchants live in crowded, narrow, and steep switchback streets built precariously along the beach’s steep cliffs, and the Mages’ enormous towers soar high above the cliffs like jagged teeth.

On the beach itself, trained cannon crabs ward off any plunderers and a single fortified pier allows merchant vessels to trade with Vel.

Vel’s influence is felt far and wide internationally, and the Mages of the Beach have a thinly concealed desire to dominate the world, first through the soft power of influence and then through the hard power of conquest.

Academic. The Mages of the Beach have a large university in one of their central towers. They commonly invite well-known scholars to spend time teaching in their university’s halls, and while scholars visit Vel, the Mages aggressively try to brainwash these scholars to mirror Vel’s philosophical talking points when the scholars set forth for other universities.

Aristocratic and Political. The Mages of the Beach hold unquestionable control over every aspect of life in Vel. Any administrative position or legal office is held by a Mage of the Beach.

Mercantile and Trade. Vel is currently pursuing an international strategy of soft influence. They export entertainment goods, games, novels, and leisure activities, trying to inculcate Velan culture into every other nation on Gathandia.

Highly interested in the city-state of Husk for its location on a point of power, Velan scholars are working on developing a way to open a permanent teleportation portal between two areas so that they can trade with Husk much more readily.

Militant. Under the command of General Vilhelm Cynthar, a skilled combat mage, Vel’s military is highly trained and effective. Every Velan soldier is capable of basic magic casting of some kind and is trained in fighting with unique magical weapons.

Religious. The Mages of the Beach have introduced a unique religion to Vel. Many gods are inscribed on illuminated cards, which citizens are encouraged to buy and trade. The Mages of the Beach started with pantheons that are commonly accepted throughout Gathandia, and released fewer copies of certain gods to increase their scarcity. The more god-points you have, the more religious you are and the more blessed you will be, the Mages declare.

They have released several “seasons” of cards and have made up a vast number of fictitious pantheons so that they can keep printing more and more cards. The more cards that they print, the higher number of god-points a commoner will need in order to maintain their good fortune.

Their bastardization of religion for personal profit is utterly disgraceful. Tovare forgive me, but I hope the whole lot of them rot in the dungeons of Melaneth.

-Marcus

Social. It is governmentally required that every merchant and every commoner is happy and merry at least 80% of any given week. In order to promote this idea, mandatory festivals and gaming tournaments are commonplace.

Underworld. The vigilant diviners among the Mages of the Beach are constantly on the lookout for signs of criminal conspiracies and are quick to make examples of anyone who gets conspiratorial inclinations. They do not tolerate black markets in Vel, but encourage Velan merchants to engage in black market negotiations in other nations.

QUEST IDEAS

  • The heroes might have a run-in with Velan merchants or mages anywhere in Gathandia. This may lead the heroes to look for a way to reduce Vel’s influence or even overthrow the malignant city-state entirely.

YODVAN

Long ago, the bravest sailors from Fjordenhaven braved the Ice Seas of the north and made landfall on a strange and wondrous island of snow. They explored a forest whose plants seemed to be made of a vegetable-metallic hybrid and ventured into the fog-choked mountains beyond. There, they found Yodvan’s true treasure: a mythically hard and strong material that came to be known as adamantine.

Several expeditions later, the Fjordenhavians had sent enough people and supplies to this island that they were able to establish a permanent outpost. It grew into a city, and from there several more towns were established as eager miners and explorers ventured into the Glowing Forest and the Mountains of Adamant. Eventually, facing political pressure from his youngest sister and struggling to manage Fjordenhaven proper and the distant island of Yodvan, the king of Fjordenhaven gave the island of Yodvan to his sister as an independent nation.

The snowblown island of Yodvan experiences days where the sun does not set during the summer, and experiences long nights during winter. In the darkest days of winter, the sun does not rise at all.

Academic. Aurora’s Hearth, the capital of Yodvan, has a large scientific academy that conducts endless experimentation with adamantine and the various biotechnical discoveries that explorers find in the Glowing Forest.

Aristocratic and Political. Like Fjordenhaven, Yodvan practices a monarchy of pure primogeniture: the eldest child of each monarch becomes the next monarch. Subsequent children (or other family members) are assigned to be counts and countesses over Yodvan’s towns.

Mercantile and Trade. To this day, Yodvan remains independent but is closely allied with its parent nation: Fjordenhven sends foodstuffs to Yodvan in exchange for an influx of glass lights and adamantine. Yodvan can sell its commodity goods for enormous returns in virtually any nation that it can reach.

A bulb of pear-shaped glass that emanates light… What other wonders might this strange island hold?

-Belozog

Militant. Yodvan does not have a standing infantry, but has highly trained and well equipped town guards. Most town guards have “electric torches” fashioned from the glowing glass lights that people harvest from the forest. They are also equipped with adamantine shields and spears, making them quite tough to beat. Yodvan does maintain a reasonably powerful navy with vessels and sailors that are well-equipped for dealing with icy waters.

Religious. Yodvan observes many of the same religious practices that are held by their southern neighboring nation, Noord. Most folk worship both winter as a harsh but strengthening goddess, and Aurora - the northern lights - as a goddess of bounty, beauty, and good fortune. They also pay homage to the Fjordenhavian patron god of fire, Aeshir, but he is not as prominent in Yodvanian religion as Aurora or Strack, the winter.

Social. Yodvan’s culture is a blend of Fjordenhaven’s and Noord’s. Having generally adopted the religious beliefs of Noord, Yodvan has the less militant attitude shared by the Fjordenhavians. The folk of Yodvan are generally warm and hospitable to strangers, but punish crime very severely.

Underworld. A thriving crime syndicate constantly smuggles new inventions from Yodvan out to the rest of the criminal world throughout Gathandia. This is dangerous work: if caught, thieves are dumped in frigid water and left to the fish. Even so, the lucrative profit is enough to lure many into this line of work.

AURORA’S HEARTH

Aurora’s Hearth is the first outpost founded by Fjordenhaven hundreds of years ago. It has since developed into a sprawling city that hugs the coastline for dozens of miles. The old town, where Fjordenhavian sailors first made landfall, is where the monarch’s palace stands tall and proud against the cold. The Yodvanian Academy of Sciences is a few miles south of the old town.

Aurora’s Hearth is clean, well-maintained, and well-lit at night, thanks to the glowing glass lights harvested from the forest. The city watchguards do an excellent job of mitigating violent crime and home burglary, but struggle to tamp down on controlled goods being smuggled out of the city’s numerous ports.

POINTS OF INTEREST

The Glowing Forest. The glowing forest was created from ancient Avadri technology, though this has not yet been discovered by Yodvanian researchers. Its vegetation grows in strangely intentional patterns: trees might have limbs at precise angles, and a bush’s leaves might all be exactly the same size. The vegetation seems to be made of an alloy of both plant and metal materials, and scientists are still experimenting with the best uses for this material. Glass bulbs grow from many trees and bushes in a variety of shapes, and these bulbs will often glow with internal light. Scientists have discovered how to control when these lights turn on and off, and the bulb’s light will last for several years after being plucked.

Other discoveries no doubt lie deep in the Glowing Forest, but strange monsters of untold power lurk in the forest’s depths as well. Determined but cautious, the Yodvanians have made slow progress in uncovering the secrets within the forest’s depths.

The Mountains of Adamant. Shrouded in thick fog and palpable mystery, the Mountains of Adamant loom cold and foreboding along the center of the large island. The promise of great wealth in the form of adamantine lures many miners and adventurers, but both the terrain and the fauna are vicious in these mountains, not to mention the winds that could rip flesh from bone. Jagged cliffs, treacherous glaciers, and narrow passes each pose threats to explorers. Terrifying creatures that lurk deep in the mountain’s caves often leave even stoic heroes babbling with inarticulate fright.

QUEST IDEAS

  • Yodvan holds many valuable materials, notably adamantine and glowing glass. The heroes might be recruited by Yodvanian scientists or by patrons from another nation to travel deeper into the Glowing Forest or the Mountains of Adamant to find more of these materials or to make new discoveries.
  • An eldritch being has awakened in a mineshaft in the Mountains of Adamant, and so officials call on the heroes to stop the monster before it can cause lasting damage.
  • An incredibly brutal winter has completely buried a town in snow. The heroes must oversee efforts to rescue the town, but starving polar bears and hungry abominations from the Glowing Forest have other ideas for the town’s trapped citizens.
  • The heroes are recruited by a network of magic item smugglers working for Husk or Vel. They want the heroes’ help in procuring a new item that scientists have created with the plant-metal of the Glowing Forest.

PLANES OF EXISTENCE

Gathandia and Ancerra are not the only places that daring heroes might explore. Adventurers, especially those of higher character level, might journey into the planes of existence beyond the mortal coil. Ancerra and other worlds on the same plane of existence are believed to be on the “Prime Material” plane, according to planar scholars.

AVADRIA

Once a plane of boundless light and radiant creations, the Eon War between the Paragon and Corrupted Avadri destroyed Avadria’s former splendor. It is now a silent, desolate plane filled with tendrils of the Pale and debris of millions of dead worlds. Avadria consists of entire galaxies that have gone dark. Cold, lightless stars still form the centers of silent solar systems and lifeless mechanical planets orbit around them.

There is no gravity here, and the space is breathable even when between planets. There is no light whatsoever, and the shadows seem to actively eat away at any light source. Terrors larger than planets stalk the umbral plains, surviving off of the refuse of an obliterated civilization. Maddened fae linger here, as well as denizens of the Pale.

Many scholars believe that the enormous machines that orbit dormant in these galaxies will one day awaken again and either set their galaxies back in order or break out of Avadria, bringing the plane’s desolation to the whole multiverse.

POINTS OF INTEREST

Alshahath. The ruined shell of Alshahath, homeworld of the Avadri, still drifts through empty space as its star detonated eons ago. Its surface a mess of molten metal and frigid wastelands, the technology possibly contained within the deepest recesses of the planet holds the power to ascend any mortal to godhood or beyond.

The Star-Forges. The various star-forges and world-forges that survived the Eon War still retain the ability to create and disassemble entire solar systems. Anyone capable of harnessing these massive machines in their full power can create their own demi-planar planet.

Thyre. Thyre, last fortress of the scattered Avadri resistance, lies at the intersection between Avadria and the long-forgotten Fundamental Plane. The entire planet has been converted to a colossal warcamp, radiant structures forming a majority of its observable landscape. The air and sky are near absolutely pure. The Avadri guardians who are still alive dwell within this bastion.

THE CELESTIAL SEA

The Celestial Sea is a vast planar ocean that connects the Prime Existence, Avadria, Everwilds, Inferno, and Iztari. It allows safe travel between planes without having to travel through the dangerous Pale, which envelops the Celestial Sea on all sides beyond the planes.

The Celestial Sea always teems with trillions of stars, but these are not physical stars that produce heat and energy. Instead, stars on the Celestial Sea are bits of Essence that form together to create souls.

SOULS AND ESSENCE

A soul is the Essence cultivated within a single living creature. One soul cannot live multiple times, because when a creature dies and their Essence returns to the Celestial Sea, their Essence doesn’t remain stuck together. This makes resurrection impossible after a number of years, depending on how long it takes for a Soul’s Essence to dissolve back into the Celestial Sea.

This is also why some Resurrection results in a person having their personality changed, some of their memory being lost, or some other combination of unique mental/personality challenges: a person’s Soul might have begun to dissolve, and when they are forcibly resurrected back into a body then the process might bring back their incomplete Essence or might bring other ambient Essence (perhaps Essence that was once part of a different soul and still has different memories and personality associated with it) back into the same body.

THE EVERWILDS

The Everwilds are an endless tangle of dramatic natural landscapes. Sprawling deserts, enormous forests full of towering trees, blizzard-scoured tundras, and impossibly deep oceans all jumble together in an illogical swirl. While towns and settlements exist in the Everwilds, it is truly the domain of nature. Each natural environment is at its most dramatic in the Everwilds.

Travelers who journey into the Everwilds will quickly realize that space and time are relative in this plane. Adventurers may journey across a sweeping grassland towards a towering mountain; while the mountain looks to be a day’s journey away, it may take them an hour or a week to reach the mountain. They will also find, upon returning to the Prime Material, that a week in the Everwilds might have only been half that time in the Prime Material. Other travelers experience the opposite, realizing that two weeks have passed in Ancerra for every week they spent in the Everwilds.

Of all the planes outside of the Prime Material, the Everwilds has the most portals. It is easier to travel back and forth between the Prime Material and the Everwilds than any other plane, either through the use of spells or through finding numerous magical portals throughout the world. Because of this, there is quite a strong presence of fae creatures and fae humanoids in Ancerra, and humanoid settlements in the Everwilds are not very uncommon.

Much of the Everwilds is a collage of dramatic natural landscapes that do not follow the natural laws of weather and terrain. Jungles may border on tundras, which might in turn give way to tropical archipelagos. However, the six Archfae Conclaves exert significant influence on the land immediately around them. The natural environment around each conclave reflects the general disposition of the conclave’s members.

The six Archfae Conclaves, along with their basic attitudes and how this shapes the world around them, are described below.

ASHYIDIR

The Ashyidir Conclave embodies the four prime elements - fire, water, earth, and air - along with their derivatives. Fire and water together make steam, while fire and earth make magma, for example. The Ashyidir have a variety of dispositions but are generally driven by emotion rather than deliberative thought. The natural environment around the Ashyidir Conclave morphs to emphasize the four prime elements. Islands might float in the sky, waterfalls might flow upwards, and forest fires might be more common.

LETSPINA

The six Archfae of the Letspina Conclave each represent one of the six senses typical to mammals: touch, taste, sight, hearing, smell, and instinct. They are generally curious about the world, trying to gain more input about their surroundings and unlikely to make hasty decisions. The natural world near the Letspina Conclave is especially vibrant.

Some might relish the sensory overload: the wind feels a little sharper, the rustling grass sounds a little more crisp. Others might find this a bit overwhelming.

PASHAK

The Pashak Conclave consists of Archfae that represent the spiritual embodiment of various plants. They are generally seen as the slowest and most deliberative out of the conclaves, and consequently are typically considered the wisest. The vegetation around the Pashak Conclave is the healthiest in the entire multiverse.

SHIBMAR

Archfae of the Shibmar Conclave are the embodiments of many different animals. The personalities of each Shibmar Archfae reflect more of the animal’s spiritual characteristics than the physical, as virtually every animal seeks food, shelter, and companionship in approximately that order. Animals in close proximity to the Shibmar Conclave are highly intelligent compared to their mundane kin; some can even speak fluently.

STRAVON

The Stravon Conclave is the most mischievous of the six. The Archfae in this conclave each embody a dichotomy of emotions, such as love and hate. Oberon and Titania, the king and queen of this conclave, are at times volatile and at times deliberative. Many Stravon Archfae enjoy playing practical jokes on other Archfae and on mortals. The natural world near the Stravon Conclave is more prone to odd juxtapositions of environments, such as jungle trees growing out of a glacier.

VERTUMNA

The Vertumna Conclave is the smallest conclave, with only four Archfae. They each represent a season and work with one another in perfect synchrony. Unlike the other conclaves, which often bicker internally, the Vertumna understand that each of them play a crucial role in the progression of time. Without spring rains, crops would fail, and without winter’s snows, rivers that rely on runoff might dry up. The natural world near the Vertumna Conclave is the most stable and recognizable to a traveler from the Prime Material. Seasons progress logically in Vertumna territory, and plants grow in their appropriate environs.

INFERNO

Though Inferno itself functions outside the normal senses and structures of mortal existence, the Fiends are well known as the very embodiment of malicious and evil intent. The landscape of Inferno is similarly malicious, though it is unknown whether the terrifying and hostile plane is a result of Fiends that inhabit it or if the Fiends are a result of their environment. Philosophy aside, it is certain that Inferno is one of the most dangerous and inhospitable places any mortal could find themselves.

Time and space move differently in Inferno than they do in the Prime Material, making distance and proximity impossible to measure, and one’s perception of being is heavily influenced by the willpower of an individual. A mortal might find themselves walking the same lonely stretch of 100 yards for years or moving across entire continents in a single step. Countless spirits who have dared enter Inferno have simply vanished, fragmented through mind-breaking confusion and lost to fog of incomprehension, without ever laying eyes on the malefic Fiends that stalk its recesses. These are the luckiest travelers to Inferno.

Inferno’s hellscape is divided into four domains, each with distinct topology and nightmarish creatures.

The Cholereth, Melaneth, Phlegmereth, and Sanguineth are the four broadest categories of fiend into which most fiends can be sorted, and these are also the names that scholars use to refer to the four regions of Inferno. Each domain also has one defining characteristic.

The Exiles, having been expelled from Iztari, make their home in Inferno as well. Many of them, especially Mikhael, have risen to prominence and are capable of contesting the archfiends for dominance over Inferno’s regions.

CHOLERETH

Dominated by the burning desert of Kalk’gahrak, the domain of Cholereth stretches endlessly as a brutal waste. Ash and coal intermingles with glass-sharp sand beneath a blood-red sky. Across these dunes, warbands of Cholereth fiends lead an endless slaughter as they fight for dominance with greater archfiends in an effort to dominate the region. These conflicts may last thousands of years before one fiend is finally victorious and moves on to battle the next fiend.

MELANETH

Durlossoth, the Black City, is an endless collection of tightly packed stone buildings in various stages of decay and ruin. Occupying the whole of Melaneth, the Black City is full of nonsensical alleyways that twist between structures of no unifying architecture.

Overhead, a cloudy sky is stuck in perpetual twilight. The streets seem to shift around its lost wanderers, keeping souls from ever finding their way out. Pale-skinned Melaneth fiends stalk the shadows as gaunt, hunched figures of bone and sinew with hollow eye sockets and twisting voids of blackness at their cores. They are just as likely to welcome you with disingenuous fang-toothed smiles as they are to jump upon you with hooked claws and crude weapons. The buildings themselves come in every shape and size but always contain neglected furnishings of gnarled black wood.

The Obsidian Palace. At the heart of Durlossoth stands a grand palace carved from one solid piece of obsidian. Fortifications and spires loom over the ruined buildings, sprouting countless ballista and defensive emplacements. These sit unmanned and forgotten. The great obsidian gates are left ajar so that any who come upon the palace may enter freely. Inside, grand halls stretch for miles with all the trappings one might expect to find from noble holdings, each room seeming like the occupants left only moments before. Great paintings depict unidentifiable conflicts, the spilling of blood, countless representations of suffering, and twisted portraits with screaming faces. At the center of it all is the throne room of Sahrnulothon, Prince of Ruin.

PHLEGMERETH

The embodiments of plague and infection, the fiends of Phlegmereth lurk in the silent bog of Xarnoas. The landscape of Xarnoas consists of flat, sparse boglands covered in a sea of needle-sharp blades of grass, occasionally interrupted by stagnant pools of icy-cold water. Xarnoas is almost completely silent aside from the buzzing that emanates from thick clouds of stinging insects that swarm across the waterways. Very few creatures live in this miserable place, but that does not make it any less dangerous. Large ambush predators vaguely reminiscent of crocodiles lie in wait in the shallows. Bulbous mounds of fungus sprout whipping protrusions that infect any they sting with rotting, transformative growths. Diseases are rampant here, and every paper-thin cut leaves a body in life-threatening danger from infection.

The Cathedral of Phlegm. While villages of stilted hovels can be found throughout Xarnoas, only one lasting structure stands at its heart. The Cathedral of Phlegm is a massive ruin of ancient stones from an unknown era now sagging into the soft earth. Thick, stinking moss threatens to swallow the cathedral whole. The Six Bishops, the rulers of Phlegmereth, meditate on the power of plague amongst a flock of infected fiends and other unfortunate beings forever cursed with maladies of every horrific imagining. These powerful archfiends are not immune to the spread of illness, instead seeing every pustule and rash as a sign of divine favor worthy of excessive meditation and reflection.

SANGUINETH

The jungles of Ogshora, also known as “the Red Glade,” dominates the domain of the Sanguineth. Thick, hot air chokes fetid waterways of coppery red liquid similar in taste and smell to mortal blood. These streams flow around large copses of fleshy, tumorous growths that resemble mangrove trees. Blood-sucking leeches, giant bloated ticks, toxic frogs, and swarms of carnivorous birds are some of the creatures one might encounter in these horrid jungles. The plant life is just as deadly.

The Den of Delights. Deep within the Red Glade, the most unlucky travelers will find the home of Ogshora’s archfiend prince, Thaniasmos. The Den of Delights is an ancient ruin draped in flayed skins still dripping with blood. Thaniasmos feeds off of the emotions of mortals like a connoisseur sampling the finest of wines. Thaniasmos’s most prized souls are kept in torment for ages as their spirits are slowly consumed in the most prolonged and painful of ways.

IZTARI

The dramatic and beautiful plane of Iztari is home of the celestials. The plane is structured as an enormous, gently sloping mountain that never becomes too difficult to breathe despite its great heights. The snow at the peak of the mountain is pleasantly cold but never causes serious frostbite. Similarly, the whitewater rapids that cascade down the mountain never drown anyone, as the water is magically breathable. Various celestial creatures dwell on the different elevations of the mountain. Ponycorns graze in the lush foothills, Chamroshes Sphinxes soar above the treetops, Daeva and Narai splash in the waterfalls, and the Celestial Council oversees it all.

At the top of the mountain, the Celestial Council’s great hall is carved from brilliant marble. Within this hall, the Council debates over planar legislation and argues whether they should allow the Exiles to return from Inferno and rejoin the ranks of the Celestials.

THE EXILES

Thousands of years ago, when factions of Celestials found themselves unable to reach a consensus regarding their role as planar protectors, heated debate boiled into war. Tovare and her defenders eventually won the war and they cast out the dissidents, Mikhael and his followers, consigning them to eternity in Inferno. Rather than simply accepting their punishment, Mikhael and his followers set about warring with the archfiends and trying to become the new lords of Inferno.

THE PALE

The Pale is the space in between. It is the edge of creation. Whatever darkness is to light, the Pale is to reality. It is a blank canvas to the most powerful gods, and incomprehensible to most mortals. Eldritch beings lurk within the Pale as crawling things hide in the shadows.

What lives in the pale could drive most intelligent beings insane by simply gazing upon it. What comes out of the pale are nightmarish, otherworldly outsiders that are hard to even keep record of. Even the words on the page crawl. Beings without powerful magic to shield their mind cannot enter the Pale.

INTERNATIONAL GUILDS

In addition to the many nations of Gathandia, international guilds are also major players on the continent. Note that this section deals specifically with guilds that hold an international presence and are not explicitly associated with a nation. Falthic crime syndicates, for example, do not have a dedicated entry here as they are closely tied to the nation of Falth.

CRIME SYNDICATES

ARDENTS

Based in Roshallan, the Ardents are a covert order of zealots who believe that Roshallan’s aggression and annexation of other nations is unforgivable. The Ardents view themselves as the tools of the divine, as just punishment for Roshallan’s actions. Ardents believe that they are morally superior to crime syndicates - the Ardents act out of a strong desire for justice, while criminal entities act out of a drive for profit. Even so, Ardents will begrudgingly make alliances with any network, criminal or otherwise, that might help weaken Roshallan in some way. The Ardents also implement assassination and skullduggery to weaken Roshallan’s imperial grip on its provinces.

HARLAN’S GUILD

Harlan’s Guild has many interests and is known best as a magic items smuggling operation. By thieving from caravans and robbing stores known to keep magic items in stock, Harlan’s Guild then resells these items on the black market. When other syndicates in their territory try to get in on magic item fencing, Harlan’s Guild takes very unkindly to this and harrasse the up and coming syndicate until they back off of the market.

The Guild is well known for crafting unique poisons with which they coat their weapons. They use these poisons to gain an edge when they must fight, and they are not afraid of trading blows when needed. Robbing stores or caravans that traffic magic items is usually a dangerous and bloody ordeal, so these poisons are integral to giving them an upper hand in their heists.

Harlan’s Guild is a widespread network sprawling across most of Gathandia. Its headquarters is in Falth, where Harlan himself governs Breachvale, a large city on Nalathesh’s border.

Guild Poisons

Members of Harlan’s Guild readily have access to these three poisons. Harlan’s Guild can also access many more poisons; these are simply their specialties and are always available to guild members.

Drake’s Breath: After application, your attacks with that weapon have a 50% chance to deal +1d6 fire damage for 1 minute. The extra damage occurs on odd-numbered attack rolls.

Ice Blood: The first target struck with a weapon coated in this poison must make an END check with a DC of 10 at the start of their turns for the next 1 minute. On any turn where they fail, they gain the Chilled condition.

Harlan’s Breach: After application, your attacks with that weapon ignore all Resist properties, as well as Immune Blunt, Immune Sharp, and Immune Physical, for 1 minute.

ICEGRAVE

Icegrave is a relatively small but effective crime syndicate that operates in the far north. Its headquarters is in a small, fortified town tucked away in a treacherous mountain pass in northern Noord. Icegrave also has major operating cells throughout Yodvan and even has a small presence as far south as Nalathesh, where Icegrave’s operatives sell their smuggled goods to Falthic crime guilds, the Scorpions, and other black market buyers.

Icegrave primarily concerns itself with the theft and black market selling of the strange materials taken from the Glowing Forest. Chiefly a syndicate of smugglers, Icegrave will nonetheless take on other jobs when the opportunity and potential rewards are great enough.

MUL’ATOR

Originally based in Betaal, the Mul’Ator have since been exiled for their bloodthirsty reputation. They were a faction of the Shinus that still dwell in Betaal, but have since become their own organization. Nobody knows where they are headquartered now - nobody except for Felson Weskh, who has bought their loyalty and who pays for them to maintain a headquarters in Gavare even as they report to him directly.

The Mul’Ator have a reputation for being unparalleled assassins who seem to revel in dismembering their victims and leaving their corpses as gruesome monuments to death. They operate all across Gathandia, and when a wealthy and influential person wants to hire a brutal assassin, they need turn no farther than the Mul’Ator.

SCORPIONS

Masquerading as a simple merchant caravan, the Scorpions are a dangerous and unpredictable crime guild. They operate primarily in Nalathesh, Kandif, and Lesmishan, but are known to travel as far east as Kendaria and as far south as the Thunderhead Vale.

The Scorpions could almost be considered a mercenary group, as they will take jobs for high-paying patrons but will also rob and bully other merchant caravans. They primarily facilitate international black market trade by transporting illicit goods across their vast territory. This is usually a lucrative business, but they will turn to their more violent acts - robbing other caravans and even raiding towns - when the black market is in a dry season.

UNDERMINERS

Based in Bridgemoor but operating along the entire east coast of Gathandia - and even as far west as Nalathesh - the Underminers are a crime syndicate with strong cult elements. Many members of the Hierophants are also involved with the Underminers due to the Underminers’ quasi-religious fascination with the Avadri. The Underminers believe that gaining a better understanding of the Avadri will allow them to reshape the world, much as the Avadri shaped the world ages ago. The Underminers primarily consist of thieves and smugglers that amass Avadrium and other magical objects, and of scientists who experiment with these materials to discover new uses of them. When possible, the Underminers also destabilize local governments or place their own members in seats of power so that they can prepare the way for their idea of a greater future.

THE WEB

An expansive crime syndicate that prominently stretches across the western half of Gathandia and even has a few operatives east of the Cloudpiercers, this secretive syndicate is known simply as the Web. Its members are some of the most unobtrusive, trustworthy-looking folk in any given settlement. Grandmotherly herbalists, kindly general store owners, and bumbling town guards all might be members of the Web. Members can identify one another by their decorative doilies, which they keep hidden in plain sight in their stores, homes, or with their belongings. The Web’s mission is to destroy the Illuminati by exposing and discrediting its members, and they are willing to employ any means necessary according to the skill set of their local members.

The Web believes that the Illuminati suppresses the freedoms and privacy of the people throughout Gathandia, and seek to dispel what they view as a corrupt and tyrannical shadow over the land.

MAGICAL GUILDS

THE CABINET

The Cabinet is a secret council of twelve masters of psionic magic. They oversee instructors, who in turn train hundreds of psionic latents. The Cabinet’s instructors often also serve as neutral advisors to many nations and are dispersed across Ancerra, serving as translators, diplomats, and long-distance telepathic communicators. A representative from the Cabinet serves as a symbol of status and lends legitimacy to a nation’s leader.

When one of the Cabinet’s twelve masters knows that they will soon pass on, they choose a protege to take their place. This is generally a well-respected member of the Cabinet with a strong record as an instructor or advisor. When one of the Cabinet’s twelve masters finally dies, their physical body deteriorates, but their Essence lives on in a shared Mind Palace accessible by all of the twelve.

THE CULTIVATORS

Cultivators typically practice divine magic, and if they do not then they still ascribe to the higher principles of their gods - especially Tovare, the head matron of the Celestial Council. They take vows of poverty, humility, and chastity and commonly travel throughout Ancerra to the poorest communities to help them develop. Some Cultivators travel to many communities over the course of their lives, never settling down, and others (typically the wiser ones) focus on one or two key communities and spend their whole lives and livelihoods helping those specific communities. Cultivators that settle in specific communities often become cherished members of society, while those that travel around more can be seen as out of touch.

THE FIXERS

The Fixers is an institution of psionic casters that boasts thousands of members throughout Ancerra. They primarily view themselves as the solutions to direct problems like collapsed bridges or roving monsters. They travel their regions to collect bounties, defeat monsters that are troubling settlements, and telekinetically repair infrastructure.

HAVEN CONCLAVE

The Haven Conclave are guides and sentinels skillful in the natural world. Many members of the Haven Conclave are rangers, oracles, and witches, and most can use at least a little primal magic.

Haven cloisters offer shelter and solace from the storm. Haven sentinels stand on the edges of the more depraved elements of wilderness, defending innocent settlements and beasts alike from unnatural threats. Guides often offer their services to merchants or adventuring parties struggling to navigate a fearsome land.

THE HIEROPHANTS

The Hierophants are an esoteric divine organization. Prophets of the avadri, the Hierophants believe that they can learn to divine the future by deciphering the coding written into the universe. The organization is small and reclusive, but widespread. If one knows where to look and whom to ask after, a clever investigator can usually find a Hierophant alcove.

ILLUMINATI

An order of arcane casters who consider themselves more knowledgeable and more discerning than any other order, the Illuminati master arcane divining, enchanting, and illusory magic. Members of the Illuminati keep their affiliation secret and communicate with one another covertly. Members of the Illuminati range from prominent scholars to minor nobles to monarchs of entire kingdoms. They use their collective wealth, knowledge, and influence to steer the geopolitics of Gathandia as they see fit. While they strive to keep the whole of Gathandia safe and peaceful, their means are often seen as invasive. The largest concentration of Illuminati dwell in Valstrom, and Valstrom’s monarch is one of the preeminent members of the organization.

LIGHTS FROM BELOW

Colloquially known as Lebellos or Elbes, the Lights from Below is a small wing of psions dedicated to improving Ancerra. The Lights from Below use their telekinetic powers to construct bridges and dig wells. Those with psionic powers of persuasion will dissuade bandits and monsters from their violent actions. Members of the Lights from Below do not seek wealth or fame from the outside world, taking internal satisfaction in their work. While traveling, full members will nurture young latents. Their headquarters, the Hall of Heroes, is a massive hall carved into a mountain face in the Cloudpiercer Range. It is filled with statues and frieze sculptures that depict heroes from the organization and their famous adventures.

PATH OF ASCENDANCY

The Path of Ascendancy is an infamous school of the occult. Ascendants profess that anyone can become a god in their own right if they try hard enough and are willing to sacrifice enough; this sacrifice comes with immense physical and mental toll. For new initiates in the Path to advance in rank, they must bring in additional new initiates.

Ascendants cast their magic by drawing intricate, beautifully complex geometric shapes. Many Ascendants get these shapes tattooed on themselves as signs of rank, belonging, and power.

The Great Ascendant is the leader of the Path. Although once human, he has undergone so many permanent transformations that he now looks like an archfiend. He has goat legs, huge claws, cat eyes, ram horns, a snake’s tongue and fangs, and enormous bat wings. Every inch of once-human flesh has been burned and branded so many times that it’s as tough as leather and as red as raw meat. His skin is also covered in geometric tattoos that are never quite symmetrical.

REWEAVERS

A widespread and decentralized organization of arcane casters specializing in alchemy and altering, members of the Reweavers are a welcome sight in any struggling town. Capable of quickly repairing and rebuilding basic objects and even whole buildings, Reweavers believe that their magical powers should be freely shared with those in need. Reweavers are generally content to receive a modest income and free room and board for their services, caring not for great wealth. While the Reweavers do not have an official home and can be found in most nations, they are most active in Anedonia and Doshairiel. They used to operate widely in the region that is now Roshallan, but as the empire took over many of the Reweavers looked elsewhere. Roshallan’s effective infrastructure and its tyrannical rule gave Reweavers both little reason to stay, and great reason to leave.

SAVANTS OF THE PALE

By focusing on the mystical mists of the Pale, members of this cryptic institution learn how to hide and obscure their tracks. They believe that this is of fundamental importance, because once they become experts at hiding their magical presence, they can steal more powerful abilities from gods and planar beings and escape undetected, free to use their newfound powers however they please. Casters from this group are notable for wearing deep, hooded cloaks and for casting occult magic by singing strange, dissonant choral melodies.

SOOTHSAYERS

A monastic collection of hermits, most of whom have oracular abilities, dwell in the Cloudpiercer Range in and around Betaal. As their numbers have grown, some have migrated and started new monastic communities to the south and west. These folk, known as the Soothsayers, have untold powers of divining. They typically keep to themselves, living within their own monasteries and only traveling into the greater world when they feel that a great prophecy must be shared.

Some Soothsayers share prophecies with specific kingdoms or even specific people, while others prophesy to a broader audience.

The founder of the Soothsayers, Elindira Stavrelyden, began manifesting psionic divining abilities even before magic was widespread. She predicted the Tear exactly one year before it happened, down to the very minute.

STORM CONCLAVE

Members of the Storm Conclave are vengeful naturalists trying to burn down society and return everyone to hunter-gatherer lifestyles, as this is the way that they believe nature intended for humanity to live. They especially target international trading groups such as the WGC, or popular routes utilized by intercity merchants such as the Golden Road, trying to destabilize the veins of modern living and return the world to its days of so-called glory.

SURROGATES

A small and ambitious group of arcanists, the Surrogates specialize in summoning magic, taking their name from the fact that they conjure forth other creatures to act in their place. Primarily operating in Doshairiel and Nalathesh, the Surrogates strongly oppose the Unsoiled. The Surrogates profess that reanimating a corpse to do manual labor or any other task is disrespectful to the memory of the person, and that summoning other creatures is not only more humane, but also more effective as one can summon a creature suited to the task at hand. The Unsoiled, in turn, argue that any living creature should be free to do as it wishes while the dead see to the grunt work of society. The two groups often get into verbal - and sometimes physical - bouts with one another.

UNSOILED

Some arcanists hold that the greatest stain on humanoid achievement is death. None have been able to outsmart it or outrun it. Some powerful psions live on as ghostly presences in their mind palaces, and some druids - especially elven druids - might live for a thousand or more years before they die, but even they cannot guarantee that their bodies will never fade.

The Unsoiled find this an abomination. With a contemporary understanding of magic, surely a person ought to live forever if they wish to. The Unsoiled are expert necromancers who generally use their magical abilities to help their communities. They will raid graveyards and animate skeletons to perform manual labor around a town, freeing up other folk to relax or pursue other activities.

This has been well-received in some communities, but others find the presence of the Unsoiled unnatural and repulsive. Many of the Unsoiled also aggressively pursue experimentation on humanoid corpses, trying to discern a way to extend a body’s livelihood indefinitely.

A majority of Unsoiled are well intentioned and are harmless to the public, if a bit creepy. Some, however, become transfixed by their fascination with death, and this obsession consumes them. Most famous among these is Mirva the Carver. Mirva was a Gavarese halfling with a relatively normal life. She practiced some arcane magic, but was more concerned with tending her family, including her two sons and her daughter. When a monster razed her town and tragically slaughtered her family, she turned to necromancy to revive her husband and her three children. Unfortunately, they were only shells of their former selves, so Mirva continues to seek enough power and understanding to restore their personalities. She wanders the southern Cloudpiercer Range, murdering anyone who loses their way and raising more and more corpses into her service.

VIGIL

A large, decentralized denomination that worships all Celestials and Avatars - especially those that have a militant attitude against evil and corruption, members of Vigil or “Vigilants” have sworn to protect the innocent and weak from threats that lie beyond. Some branches of Vigil are welcome in settlements that fear attacks from monsters. While all branches of Vigil are founded on good intentions, there are totalitarian branches of Vigil that do more harm than good.

W.A.N.D.

W.A.N.D. (Worldwide Arcanists who Neutralize Danger) is a large and widespread organization of mages and arcanists. Their headquarters is officially in Constel on the east coast, but W.A.N.D. has regional strongholds across all of Gathandia and, according to their leaders, maintain a presence on Ancerra’s other continents as well. W.A.N.D.’s arcanists view themselves as magic-wielding soldiers, spies, and diplomats whose primary goal is the protection of Ancerra from extraplanar threats. Occasionally, if a tyrannical regime grows strong enough to threaten the world order, then W.A.N.D. might intervene, but they generally reserve their concerns for otherworldly threats. W.A.N.D. arcanists specialize in evoking and warding magic, but many arcanists choose a third function to focus on as well.

MERCENARY ORGANIZATIONS

BLACK SOIL

A brutal mercenary band that operates in the northwest, Black Soil can typically be found in Skavr, Eryndor, and Ruptaea, though they occasionally operate in Fjordenhaven as well. This mercenary band is utterly unscrupulous, enjoying the more violent jobs with unsettling glee.

They burn, loot, and pillage towns with reckless abandon.

Black Soil also has strong cult elements and has been known to perform horrifying chants and dances in homage to the dark spirits that live in Nachtskog. Indeed, some folk whisper that the evil of Nachtskog inhabits the mercenaries of Black Soil, giving them additional strength and menace.

THE GENTLEMAN BRIGANDS

In the troubled lands of the Thunderhead Vale and the Kosia Rainforest, corruption runs rampant in most governmental institutions from the top down to local administrations. While many common folk are able to scrape together a modestly comfortable life despite this, there are many others who suffer under this inequality. The Gentleman Brigands seek to help those who cannot fend for themselves under such circumstances. They rob from the wealthy, keeping a cut to fund their own crusade and giving the rest of their spoils to those who they believe need it the most. They travel throughout the Rainforest and the Vale, willing to sell their services to the rare honest noble in exchange for better wages for the noble’s subjects. The Brigands are something of a legend throughout this region, celebrated by the poor among the society and reviled by many of the rich - especially the corrupt. The Gentleman Brigands are always led by a person known as the Hood, who passes their title on to their successor when they believe it time to lay down their own blade. The current Hood is a kleppin with the features of a red-tail fox, and his best friend and bodyguard is a grizzled Urkou named Big Butch.

RESERVES

An order of hermetic zealots, the Reserves can be found in small monasteries throughout Gathandia. They are self-sufficient communities that maintain their own sustenance farms and spin their own clothes from sheep’s wool. Besides sustaining themselves, the Reserves train rigorously for the world’s hour of need. They believe that one day, ancient threats or new foes will arise and threaten the planet’s very existence, and on this day, the Reserves will stand ready to protect existence as they know it.

THE IRON RIDERS

Equestrians skilled at mounted combat and horseback archery, the Iron Riders roam the north and west of the Great Chasm. Although it is uncommon, they can be seen as far south as Nalathesh and as far east as Derk. They primarily operate in Bishal, southern Noord, Kandiff, and Lesmishan. The Iron Riders are highly competent in desert environments and have learned how to ride their steeds such that they produce little dust, allowing them to sneak up on unsuspecting merchants. Following the basic practices of most mercenaries, the Iron Riders will leave alone those who pay their shakedown prices and will fight on behalf of those who reward them more significantly.

THE SEA SERPENTS

The Sea Serpents are an armada of pirates who prowl the eastern coast of Gathandia, from Vel in the south to Derk in the north. The Sea Serpents nominally agree that other vessels under the same flag are off-limits for piracy, but in practice, as long as there is no evidence remaining, then anything goes. Bloody ocean battles between the Sea Serpents will leave one ship sinking and in flames while the other makes off with its loot. When they feel that they are facing existential threat, however, the Sea Serpents will set aside all of their internal rivalries to take on whatever might threaten their way of life.

The Sea Serpents are based in a vast oceanic cave on the coast of Muskshir. Most Muskshiri do not condone the Sea Serpents, but are not militarily powerful enough to oust them. Aside from generalized piracy, a Sea Serpent captain and crew will take on virtually any job for well-paying clients.

Individual Sea Serpent captains will have personal flags, and the Sea Serpents’ shared flag is a white serpent on an emerald-green banner.

TYPHOON

A rowdy armada that prowls the southern seas, Typhoon is a pirate guild that will take on any job for wealthy clientele. They escort, plunder, or sink merchant vessels as asked and are not above changing sides mid-assignment if the price is right. Typhoon ships strictly do not battle one another - a rule that is maintained successfully, unlike the Sea Serpents on the east coast. Typhoon ships often clash with Roshallan’s navy and with the WGC.

As is common for seafaring folk, captains affiliated with Typhoon will fly both their personal flags and the Typhoon colors: a pale blue vortex on a black flag.

MUNDANE GUILDS

ADVENTURE ADVISOR

Adventure Advisor is a service provided to many adventurers and travelers that ranks taverns, inns, marketplaces, smithies, and even chapels according to different metrics. Each location that has an adventure advisor review is ranked on a scale of one to five shields, coins, and stars. The more shields, the safer the location is; the more coins, the greater its expenses; and the more stars the greater the overall quality and enjoyment reported by its patrons. These rankings are created using specially cultivated arcane Signatures and are only visible to people who have purchased an Adventure Advisor Assistant, which is a magical whittled owl that reveals these rankings on an establishment’s main door.

Adventure Advisor is administered by a handful of mages and arcane casters who developed their unique application of the signature cantrip to create such rankings.

ARTISANS INTERNATIONAL

Artisans International certainly has a legitimate side, but is essentially a front for an enormous crime syndicate. This company maintains showrooms, exhibits, and auctions of fine art of many varieties. Patrons can easily find paintings, fine jewelry, and elegant sculptures at these events and storefronts. Artisans International keeps detailed records of all of their transactions and has curated an elaborate system of small and large organizational operations within the umbrella company. Their international status and complicated business practices enable them to easily source, acquire, and resell fine art across Gathandia. Their methods of acquiry generally include extortion, blackmail, and burglary, and Artisans International is careful never to resell a work of art in the same city that they acquired it.

THE GOLDEN ROAD

The Golden Road is not literally a road that connects Kendaria to Anedonia, but it may as well be for how effective it is at facilitating international trade. Based and administered in Bridgemoor, the Golden Road is a collection of affiliated inns, taverns, and marketplaces that facilitate international trade. Participating locations offer deals and discounts to traveling merchants of any nationality who opt into the business. Such merchants must pay an annual dues. The administration of the Golden Road use these funds to finance renovation and monetary aid to participating locations that need such services. Locations that are members of the Golden Road must maintain a clean and safe space, lest they lose membership. The Golden Road has enabled spices, raw goods, ideas, and finished products to be disseminated across broad swathes of Gathandia.

HISTORIANS GUILD

The Historians Guild is an independent institution that catalogs historical artifacts, transcribes and translates recorded histories, and offers presentations to educate the public on historical matters. They often work in collaboration with the Order of Discerning Prewritten History and with Artisans International, both of whom are institutions with overlapping interests. The Historians Guild is controversial among people who are already deeply in touch with their historical roots because the Guild frequently buys or otherwise acquires artifacts of historical significance, removing them from their original context and placing them on display in museums. Some members of the Guild are also secretly soldiers that protect the world from ancient threats, especially those that they awaken in crypts and other archaeological sites.

Their role as silent protectors makes members of the Guild feel that they have earned the right to hoard ancient artifacts in their treasured museums.

WEST GATHANDIA TRADING COMPANY

The West Gathandia Trading Company, or WGC, is a private corporation that builds enormous deep-sea vessels in the shipyards of Pash. The WGC has warehouses and administration buildings in virtually every port city along the south and east of Gathandia, and has many established trading posts on the west coast and in the Inner Sea, as well. The WGC is currently developing vessels that should be capable of long-term voyages, allowing their crew to explore beyond Gathandia and make contact with the other continents.

Most national governments are not fond of WGC because of the company’s aggressive and monopolistic trade practices, but the wealth that they bring to the port cities is usually enough to make monarchs and other rulers begrudgingly overlook WGC’s less savory practices.

PERFORMING TROUPES

THE BUMBLEFUMBLE FESTIVAL

Hundreds of nomads travel together to put on the Bumblefumble Festival outside different cities across the continent. This festival includes carnival food and games, along with performances by the Bumblefumble bards and acrobats. Fire eaters, sword jugglers, lion tamers, and other eccentric performers also draw crowds in droves. The Bumblefumble Festival has a dark secret, however. All of their games are shams designed to separate participants from their coins while giving them just enough hope that they might win if they participate again. Most folk that work the carnival are also cunning pickpockets, lifting just a few coins at a time from their unsuspecting victims, but never stealing enough at once to raise undue suspicion. The entire carnival, which is the size of a small town when set up, can be broken down overnight, allowing the group to quickly clear out when they have overstayed their welcome. The Festival is overseen by conjoined twin halflings Bumble and Fumble, who are both skilled charlatans and can cast arcane magic, respectively specializing in enchanting and illusory functions.

CIRQUE DU PSION

A renowned and spectacular performing group that travels throughout Gathandia, especially in its southern nations, Cirque du Psion astounds commoner and noble alike.

Highly skilled acrobats enhance their performances with psionic powers, enabling them to leap to stunning heights, levitate during their somersaults, and telekinetically manipulate their silk ribbons and sparkling hoops to achieve beautiful synchronized dances. These performances are highly acclaimed and they usually fill a stadium to overflowing for several nights in a row when they perform in a highly populated town.

HARMONIEM

Nobles and other folk from high society can often be found attending performances put on by Harmoniem. This troupe of thirty talented orchestral performers travels Gathandia, performing in prestigious halls, at royal palaces, and in other highbrow locations. There are many such orchestras, but Harmoniem is by far and away the most famous. Harmoniem consists not only of the musical performers, but also skilled caravanners and security who accompany the musicians and protect them on the road.

THE MERRY MINSTRELS

The Merry Minstrels are a large, disorganized group of bards and musicians. They often travel in groups, but some strike out on their own. Whatever the case, the Merry Minstrels bring joy and cheer to the inns and taverns whence they perform. They eagerly seek out news songs and stories to add to their repertoire, informally spreading news, history, and folklore across Gathandia. Joining the Merry Minstrels is not a particularly formal process; one must perform a handful of songs or poetic recitations to a minimum of two current members of the Merry Minstrels. The most famous Merry Minstrel alive today is a six-fingered lute player named Daiquiri Fillingsworth.

STRAVONITES

Taking their name after the Stravon Conclave, the Stravonites are a traveling group of performers who put on elaborate plays. They are led by their dragonfolk playwright named Shilliam, and they have achieved international fame for their lowbrow humor and heartfelt acting. They perform most frequently in the Thunderhead Vale but have been known to travel as far west as Pash and as far northeast as Forsten.

SCHOLARLY ORDERS

ESSENCARY EPISTEMOLOGISTS

The Essencary Epistemologists are a group of scholars that travel around Gathandia giving lectures and debating with students and other scholars at any educational institution where they can find willing participants.

They can be identified by blue academic regalia with silver embroidered threading. By nature, these scholars are most interested in one’s state of being, of existing, and contemplating how the process of thinking works. They are especially interested in how Essence works, what it is, and how it affects a person’s capacity for thought and for experiencing the world. Essencary Epistemologists can be found in virtually any major university across Gathandia.

EVIDENTIARY ANALYSTS OF SCIENTIFIC PRINCIPLES

Physicists, chemists, biologists, and other scientists compose the academic guild known as the Evidentiary Analysts of Scientific Principles. They pursue both mundane and magical experimentation with alacrity, eager to better understand the workings of the physical and metaphysical. Some members of this scholarly order are themselves mages, while others are simply skilled scientists. Recognizable in their deep green academic regalia with red embroidery, these analysts can be found at any major university and some smaller academic institutions, as well. Scholars within this scientific order who specialize in astronomy and metaphysics have strenuous but constructive disagreements about the grand design of the multiverse.

ORDER OF DISCERNING PREWRITTEN HISTORY

In their light tan regalia with dark red embroidery, members of the Order of Discerning Prewritten History can be found both in the lecture hall and at archaeological sites. Scholars from this order are particularly interested in discovering and preserving anything that they can discern about ancient history, from the times before anyone began to record historical events in physical form. A mix of academic scholars, painstakingly careful archaeologists, and daring tomb raiders, members of the Order network with one another to broaden their understanding of ancient events.

The Order also corresponds regularly with the Historians Guild.

TUTORS EXTRAORDINAIRE

A nomadic and decentralized order of oracles, the Tutors Extraordinaire travel throughout Gathandia. They are highly sought after in any nation’s top universities. When a Tutor arrives in a university, they will offer classes and hands-on practice of their craft for any amount of time from a single day to multiple years. This generally depends on how beneficial a Tutor thinks that they can be to a school, but sometimes depends on the Tutor’s own whims and desires.

To become a Tutor Extraordinaire and earn the hooded sash that accompanies the rank, one must instruct classes for three years, overseen by a different Tutor Extraordinaire each year. After being approved by each of the three overseers, the teacher will be granted their sash.

WITCH COVENS

COVEN OF THE EVERWILDS

The Coven of the Everwilds is primarily located in its namesake haunt. Throughout the Everwilds, witches of this coven make their homes in villages or in the wilderness along with at least two of their fellow witches. Witches from this coven actively pursue positive relationships with the Archfae of all six Conclaves and are generally respected by fae of all types. Some cells of this coven can be found in Gathandia, especially in heavily forested areas such as the Kozia Rainforest and the nations around the northern Inner Sea. While these witches are seen as eccentric and at times creepy, many folk understand that their role as intermediaries between the mortal plane and the Archfae Conclaves is very valuable.

SYMPATHY COVEN

The Sympathy Coven is a secretive group of witches that rivals the Illuminati in influence and reach. The Sympathy Coven has far fewer witches than the Everwilds or Naturalist Covens, but these witches are cunning and powerful. Skilled in the art of creating poppets and subtly influencing the people represented by these poppets, the Sympathy Coven’s tentacles subtly pull the strings of power across Ancerra. Some members of the Sympathy Coven have designs on controlling whole empires or continents themselves, but the more altruistic members of the coven simply want to use their invisible hand to guide Gathandia’s nations away from violent conflict with one another. The Sympathy Coven often conducts acts of espionage against the Illuminati.

COVEN OF NATURALISTS

Of the three major witch covens on Gathandia, the Coven of Naturalists is the least consequential to world events. The Coven of Naturalists consists of witches who admire nature, especially its fauna. Many cells of this coven travel the world together, documenting and befriending the various beasts and monstrosities that they encounter. Others remain in roughly the same region for their whole lives and are beloved by the mundane and magical beasts of the region. A young halfling named Katsumash is believed to have the most potential to become a legendary Naturalist; although he has only been a member of the coven for a year, he has already caught the eye of several senior witches in the coven as having a particular way with animals.

TIMELINE

This timeline provides context for the nations and guilds across the continent of Gathandia. It contains much more in-depth information about Supereons One and Two as the first official campaign modules take place in these time periods.

NOTE ON TIMEKEEPING

Timekeeping in a standardized, international method is uncommon before the modern age.
